question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Lastly, we had to lead a discussion, so I learned how to create intellectual and complex questions according to a text we were asked to read.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about seeking different types of sources to build a well-rounded view, I learned about how cycles of behavior continue at all scales (personal to international), and I learned that cultural competency is critical to being able to learn about and understand things not even related to cultural.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking was important in this class. After completing the thorough readings and lectures that cleanly organized the materials, the discussions were based on going several steps forward. Professor Daly did an excellent job goading the students to think outside the box, to cumulate the knowledge learned from readings and lectures to ruminate on inferences and implications. Many times the students including myself had a difficult time answering his questions, and after a fair bit of time, the professor gave us hints and reference points to help us get to answering with our opinions. Though there were obviously wrong answers, we were not admonished for them, but were rather encouraged to be opinionated and free thinking. He wasn't controversial or biased when answering questions, and always gave us multiple facets of a given situation. This approach created a classroom dynamic of thinking beyond.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Africa'a history from European colonialism to 1990s- early 2000s. I learned about ethnic and racial tensions between African groups and between African groups and Europeans.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I personally think that critical thinking is significantly more important than just learning materials. This course succeeded in both giving us mountains of information and the ability to dissect these materials. This kind of environment is something I wish to emulate in the future if I have the opportunity to be a mentor or a teacher.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to make quick connections across different media and topics covered in African American Studies. I really got familiar with the history of Africa and how it pertains to its current cultural and economic state. I also learned about many famous names, whether authors, leaders, or academics, such as W.E.B. Du Bois, who helped advocate for Black pride and unity among shared heritage. I also gained insights on the kinds of people who helped African liberation, specifically women. I hadn't known how valuable women were to protests and advocacy against colonialism, and seeing that was both educational and empowering.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: How to think critically about the various structures that make up Africa's ontology, politics, literature, economy, and culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this class, particularly in regards to Portrayals of Africa versus the realities on ground. Whenever Africa is mentioned from a EuroWestern perspective, it is often a single narrative filled with poverty, strife, and lack of agency. So learning about how these imageries originated and continue to persist was very interesting. The continent was contextualized, in terms of the Atlantic Slave Trade and the lasting damage that EuroAmerica did to the continent and its people. But the course wasn't just a narrative of African pain. We also talked about the innovation and advancement that also exists on the continent. We talked about MPesa, the longing for travel and the Diversity Visa Program, the reciprocal process of identity creation and authenticity occurring between continental Africans and people in the diaspora, etc. It was very insightful

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text:

For example, I knew there were indigenous people in Mexico, but I had never thought to question how their status of indigeneity could change. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The small seminar class has helped facilitate various conversations that reflected some of the feelings of the students in the class. Majority of us have some sort of tie to Latin America and being able to talk about and relate to common experiences we have faced has been very validating. I also loved having the service aspect of the class. Getting out of the "Duke bubble" to engage with the Latinx Durham community was fulfilling and helped me create ties to a new community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In the course, I developed critical thinking skills when examining labels and concepts like Latino and Latinidad. I learned about the history of the Latinx community in the United States and gained insight into issues like discrimination and assimilation that followed mass migration. I learned about the relevance of music in Latinx culture and thought about the many ways it can be used to express and explore culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Coming into the class, I had some pretty big assumptions about the general content of the class. At first, I didn't think the course was going to center on US Latinx studies; I thought it was
going to focus on the history of Latin American countries and how those become affected by US intervention. Personally, I truly enjoy the direction the course is going. Learning about the history
of Latinos in the US, their struggles, their legacy, is a rich topic that I had previously not had the resources to understand. I've always wanted to learn more about this but I've never really had
the impetus to do so. I think it is so interesting to talk about these historical events, like the Chicano movement or the labor strikes, and tell my friends about them. It's a part of history that
goes unnoticed and it's worthy of bringing up everyone once in a while during a conversation. Outside of that, I feel like this class has made me more conscious of the continual Latino
presence in the US and what people are doing to combat injustice. I've done research and learned about powerful organizations, both in North Carolina and my hometown of Miami. It's
amazing seeing that everywhere there are communities like these all fighting for visibility and justice. I gain a lot from the music component of the course, and connect it to other music classes I've
taken at Duke. It's interesting seeing the connection between how the music we study is composed and what the music is representing. Understanding the Chicano movement through
song is a beautiful way to look at history. A song I particularly found touching was "Urbano's song". It was by far one of the saddest songs I've heard this year, and I still listen to it in my
 spare time.More concisely I learned:
- How to analyze Latino history and research topics in Latino studies.
- How to make a community facing project 
- How service learning can be used to supplement a class as well as engage with the surrounding community.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Kelley was exceptionally engaged in the topic of the course and it was immediately clear to the students who came to class that he loves soul music and knows a lot about the musicology behind it. He mixed in lecture components with singing, playing on the piano, and audiovisual elements that were helpful to contextualize the media we were talking about. He also made clear the differences between different types of soul and made it clear to us what we would be quizzed on and how.

course: MUSIC-146-01 : MOTOWN AND AMERICAN SOUL MUSIC.MUSIC-146-01.AAAS-146-01.

response_text: He encouraged us to try singing, clapping, and playing instruments in and outside of class, which took us outside of our comfort zone as non music majors. This was essential for our learning.For the Motown section of the class, it was extremely important for me to read about the history of Motown's founder, Barry Gordy, to get the context behind the music. This helped me be invested in learning the songs and their meanings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course completely changed my view of healthcare and what the impact of racism really is. I learned that racism has a tangible and measurable impact on people's health, this was the first time I've ever heard that racism is the reason for health disparities, because race is not a biological category in humans. I also learned about the existence of epigenetics, which I previously knew nothing about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so many new ways of thinking about health and medicine. Truly a remarkable experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I read more medical/science journals than I ever have, I improved my ability to collaborate with others, and my ability to discuss controversial issues in a civil way, especially as many of the course topics pertained to racism and marginalization in healthcare.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to engage with healthcare systems and simultaneously be sensitive to cultural practices, how to write a research paper and present on a specific population, and how to incorporate the biology aspect of epigenetics to broader ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We considered the social determinants of health and how they affect marginalized populations. We thought critically about whether or not race should be involved in health care and looked at many papers about the association between racism and genetics.

response_text: Take it. Please. The workload is incredibly light - however, I learned so much. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Importance of telomeres in aging, epigenetic changes/mechanisms, redlining

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learnt a great deal from this class. I learnt what historically has created health disparities for minorities. I learnt what health disparities are most common and how that translates to quality of life. I learnt biologically, what happens under stress that creates methylation, microRNA strands or histone acetylation and how those are linked to diseases that can even be generational.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the impacts of racism in a medical context (hospital, medical school, clinics, etc). I also learned about the meaning of epigenetics as well as its role in passing on poor/beneficial genetics to future generations. Additionally, I learned how the experiences of someone’s life can affect their generations far into the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how racism and systemically racist structures affect the health of populations in epigenetic and biological ways, rather than just as a result of the social determinants of health.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the underlying structural discrimination that leads to health disparities in the United States.I learned the changes that occur at a biological level due to epigenetic stress and how they can be reversed with adequate interventions.I learned how to synthesize different research papers and create a final paper of my own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned the biological mechanisms involved in how environmental factors can affect a person's epigenetics, such as the HPA axis and cortisol receptors.
I learned about the causes of differential health outcomes between different racial groups in the US, such as redlining.
I learned the importance of deracializing medicine, and the problems with racial bias in medicine, such as different equations for measuring pulmonary function leading to African Americans statistically getting fewer lung transplants.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I understood how to make connections between biology and socioeconomic conditions, and how they both can engage in a loop that exacerbates certain conditions. In terms of skills, I was able to write a research paper and hone my skills in doing that. And finally, I learned how to properly approach ideas and all the different facets they may have.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that there is no genetic basis for race in humans, it is purely a social construct. I learned about medical racism and how certain tests are literally designed to account for the genetic differences in humans that don't exist. I learned all about epigenetics: mechanisms like methylation, histone modification, and noncoding RNAs, why changes occur evolutionarily, what causes them, how to build resilience to them, transgenerational trauma, chronic stress, static load, and a lot more about specific instances like the adverse changes experienced by Japanese Americans forced into relocation camps (and their children). Skills I learned include researching (analyzing articles), constructing a research paper and presentation, critical thinking, and group work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned that race is a social determinant of health and is often misused in medicine. We learned about epigenetics and how genes are turned on and off. We also learned about health disparities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I developed new insights into how race is constructed in society and how systemic racism impacts healthcare today. I learned about the definitions of race, ethnicity, and ancestry. I also learned about epigenetics and how environmental factors can alter gene expression without changing the DNA. I learned about systemic racism in healthcare systems and in medical textbooks and teachings. Additionally, I learned about resilience and how to reverse the impacts on your epigenetics from adverse childhood experiences. In this class I also learned how to write a well structured research paper and present a personal project in front of the class. These new skills that I developed will be super useful in the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I completely changed my thinking regarding race based medicine and the role of epigenetic in healthcare. I learned how to interpret research papers, how to dive deeper into concepts I learned in class, and I learned how to create and present a research paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed knowledge on epigenetic that has helped me reconsider how patients should be categorized. I also learned about the true meaning of race and the lack of genetic basis, revealing the prevalence of medicalized racism in the United States. We were taught to think from multiple perspectives as we considered the various health outcomes of patient examples. We also enhanced our collaboration skills through interactive discussions and test reviews.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1- I realized how intertwined racism and overall heal can be.
2- The presentation aspect of the course allowed me to develop public speaking skills. 
3- The connection between social and biological factors made me think deeper about racism and the implications that it has on human biology.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Content: This course introduced me to global health- a field that I am excited to pursue a co-major in. The content combined my passion for history and science to deliver information on Global Health. The course, specifically, introduced me to systemic inequities in the healthcare system. I also learned about how social determinants can impact health.
2. Content: This course challenged biases within the current healthcare and medical school system. The course dismantled the concept of race and race-based medicine, focusing on how health is an outcome of historical factors. I was fascinated to learn about the stroke belt and its relation to slave states. 
3. Reading: The course involved reading some lengthier research papers-- something that I was able to get introduced to through the class. As a freshman, I was able to refine my close-reading skills to be able to understand the argument of texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class changed my ways of thinking. I became aware of the concept of epigenetics. I was able to learn the scientific basis for how one's actions, food choices, and experiences can alter their genetic expressions without making changes to the DNA sequence. I am now knowledgeable about resilience. Learning about this made me develop a locus of control. I now feel more empowered knowing that I can actively work to better my potential health outcomes. Finally, I gained insight into various populations that are more susceptible to adverse health outcomes through presentations from my peers. I am now also able to identify behaviors and/or events that may result in poor health outcomes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment was very open. Most classes had lots of information, but always with time for questions or discussions. Definitely keep all the beginning lessons (I don't have any suggestions for change) about race, genetics, and then the tie into epigenetics. 2. Speakers: The course had a variety of speakers from medical doctors to academic doctors to professors. I loved getting to engage with the speakers and prepare questions. The speakers were interwoven very well with the curriculum. I would love to be able to keep the speakers in the course.
3. Content Sequence: The content is built upon each other to provide a holistic look at the biological impact of racism. I liked the order and flow of the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my ability to analyze and write about films through motifs and directorial choices. I also learned how to connect race, gender, and sexuality theories to film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class developed my close reading/interpretation skills and my ability to focus on how specific cinematic elements tied to broader messages that the films were trying to convey. In addition, I learned more about the intersection between race, religion, and film and understand how these themes are present in various aspects of our lives. Lastly, I think I was able to develop communcaiton skills through both sharing my thinking in class as well as through the 3 analytical papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze a film for cinematographic aspects, provide close reading of film analysis, and about the afterlife of slavery.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to consider the deeper meaning in films and how camera angles, lighting, and sound contribute to the meaning of the film. I learned how to appreciate films from a cinematic framework as opposed to enjoying for pure entertainment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first course based on films and film analysis so I learned a great deal about film theory, techniques, and character development. The course allowed me to approach films I had not seen before and get a better understanding of how the film's composition ties into the meaning and application to broader society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to do a close reading of a scene in a film
2. Thinking about the different ways that blackness is framed in film
3. Exploring the intersectional nature of race, gender, religion, sexual orientation, etc

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to do a close reading of a specific scene from a film and connect it to the broader themes that we discussed in class and the readings. I learned how to analyze specific elements of the film, such as the lighting, sound, camera movements, and character decisions, and what they mean in the broader context of the film. I also improved on my essay writing over the course of the semester.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Writing film analysis; different racial and gender depictions in films (this part was very interesting!)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically analyze a movie, more specifically by breaking apart the different elements of a scene (music, lighting, prose, etc), and decipher these elements and their ability to add to a message.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Some skills and insights that I developed in this course include critical and analytical thinking, close readings of literature and film, and academic writing. 
1. In film, everything is intentional. While a major aspect of film is entertainment, films are attempt to "say" things. 
2. In order to get at what a film is trying to "say," pay attention to what's there (color, space, storytelling, dialogue, etc.) but, perhaps more importantly, note what is absent. 
3. Films converse between each other all the time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
In this course, I discovered that money is far more than just currency, it’s a cultural force. I learned that money carries deep symbolic meaning, varying across societies. For example, while dollars might seem neutral to me, other communities use shells, cattle, or digital tokens, each reflecting unique values. This shifted my perspective: money isn’t just about economics; it’s about people’s beliefs and social ties.
Finally, I explored money’s role in power structures. From colonial histories to modern cryptocurrencies, I saw how monetary systems enforce or challenge inequality. This course taught me to question assumptions—like the myth of barter, and analyze money as a tool of social control. Now, I see every transaction as part of a larger cultural story.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated how everything that we needed to know for the test was discussed in class. The readings can be lengthy at times, but if there is something you don't understand it will more than likely be clarified in class. Professor Piot lectures by asking the class questions about the readings. When a student answers, he always repeats the answers which was awesome because some students spoke very quietly. I also loved the office hours. Each time before we had an essay due I would go to office hours and they were always so happy to provide a lot of guidance. Their advice let me know exactly what they were looking for. Very helpful!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked that this course was tech free. I was 100% more engaged because there were no distractions. I also think that Professor Piot is a great lecturer and has styled the class in a way that provokes thought and encourages active listening and participation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the learning environment of this class. I enjoy a lecture-style class, and it was a bit of an adjustment but I ended up enjoying the no-slides style of the class and how the professor just talks and we listen and take notes. I like how Dr. Piot is very open to hearing from students in the class regarding our readings and also to provide their knowledge on some o the topics we were discussing. As someone who is less familiar with econ and anthropology, this allowed for me to be able to sit back and listen and learn which I really appreciated. I enjoyed the course components as well - although the readings could be dense and sometimes difficult to parse out, the fact that we would go through them in class and highlight the important information was very helpful. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this course. I found it to be super interesting and it made me think about money in ways that I never had before. The workload was very light. Each week there would be assigned readings. You don't even have to read them because Professor Piot dives deep enough into them during class which I appreciated. Our grade was made up of 2 essays and 2 exams. The essay topics were very fun to write about. I would recommend going to office hours before writing them. The TAs are extremely helpful and you can ask them literally anything. They also tell you exactly what they are looking for in the essay. The exams were good too. The way to do well on them is to go to every class (though attendance isn't required) and just write down everything that is said. If you understand your notes and read them before the test, you will do well. The test consisted of true/false questions to start and then a bunch of short answer questions. A lot of people didn't do well on the true/false section so they ended up curving that part. Overall, the course was really cool and you learn a lot about money, even though you would think you know everything about it given how common it is.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed listening to Professor Lubiano's lectures—she is one of the most intelligent and well-spoken professors I've ever met—and has a profound ability to integrate the theory and literature we encounter in class. I also appreciated how she elevated "colloquial" knowledge to the level of the academy (asking us, for example, to include hypertext and internet sources within our final paper, or bringing up the example of the online forum on dragons). This is something I haven't seen any other professor do before, and as someone who has a few reservations about the nature of literature and the academy, something I didn't take for granted. Additionally, I enjoyed the format of having one or two students come up with discussion questions for each work we talked about in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was an extremely tedious course, but the work was minimal (3 short essays and one longer final paper). Professor Lubiano is very intelligent but often struggles with conveying information, so her lectures are quite disjointed and convoluted. Many times, she would leave no room for students to speak during the entire 2.5-hour class. There was a lot of assigned reading, but, as stated, we rarely discussed them and were instead lectured at about them for 2.5 hours. And, as the lectures were so hard to follow anyway, it felt like doing the readings was pointless. If you’re looking to learn something about literature, look elsewhere. There are many other excellent professors in the English department with significantly more engaging methods of instruction.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about many important foundational elements of African diasporic performance genres, including but not limited to call-and-response and polyrhythms. 
I learned about the ways in which corporeal knowledge is embedded in various performance genres and contains important meanings of identity, cultural preservation, and resistance in the African diaspora. 
Finally, I learned about how various African diasporic performance genres have been co-opted, discredited, and misappropriated by white society.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The only thing that I learned in this course, was to never take a class taught by Tim Tyson again. While Professor Williams was lovely and kind. Tim Tyson was arrogant, condescending, and the exact opposite of what I would expect to see in a member of Duke Faculty. To start, he went on an anti semetic rant in class where he said "no one talks about jew power, but they quietly have power through the banking industry". While I am not jewish, to see this behavior from a member of such a prestigious university was disgusting. One of my friends in the class is Jewish, and the fact that he had to sit and listen to professor Tysons' ridiculous comments were insane. I also feel very afraid to take action regarding these comments, because Tyson has been extremely vindictive throughout the semester. For example, the majority of the class got an extremely poor grade on the midterm. Instead of trying to help students improve, he said "if I had taken the test I would have gotten a 100". I was one of the fortunate few students who got a B (most got a C, D, or F) however he still refused to respond to an email I sent asking him for help in the class. I hope that there is some training given to Tyson in the future to fix his anti semetic and belittling behavior.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.

response_text:
1. The specifics of the North Carolina experience prior to 1968
2. The trends of labor migration and unionization in the South 
3. Specific songs & gospel theories related to the Civil Rights Movement, Slavery, and More.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Not much, the professor was incredibly disorganized. The syllabus wasn't even on Sakai or Canvas, was on random website on safari. Dr. Tyson would just stand there from 6:30 to 9:30 and just talk, as slow and long as possible. He is not of the age to be a lecturer any more in my opinion. Every student in class would sit there on their computer for 2.5 hrs and do other hw or scroll on their computer. This was due to the fact that all he did was stand there, it was incredibly boring and unfair to students. No attempt to change anything. He is a historian and New York Times bestseller and this is what he does, but doesnt mean it will work as a teacher.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Aside from Tysons awful statements in class, the class was structured horribly. On the first day of class Tyson stated that we would have hard conversations that would help us grow. Not a single real conversation about racial relations in the south happened in this class. Instead, each week Tyson would get up there and ramble for the first 90 minutes of class. He is one of the least engaging speakers I have ever listened to. The only reprieve the class would have from Tysons rambling was when professor Williams would get up and sing. Her singing was amazing and was the only positive of each class. When it comes to the readings, Tyson assigned multiple expensive books that he wrote himself. I know that this is common for most professors, however it was extremely frustrating because the books were no different than what he discussed in class. Additionally his two most popular books have been discredited with his Emmitt Till Book being described in one news article as "Tysons Tall Tales". I have no problem paying for a book that will enhance my learning. However, when the book is filled with lies made up by a professor who does not care about his students I have a problem purchasing them.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The lectures consist primarily of Professor Tyson or Professor Williams, sharing their personal experiences and anecdotes related to the topics covered in the readings. While these lived experiences are valuable, the lectures do not delve deeper into the subject matter or provide additional information to enhance understanding. Instead, the professors tend to repeat the same stories and narratives, which does not facilitate further learning or comprehension of the material. The note cards allow students to formulate their own thoughts and make connections to the readings, but during class, the discussions are heavily focused on the professors' perspectives, leaving little room for students to share their insights or explore their connections to the topics.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The syllabus underwent changes once the class began, which is generally not permitted. Initially, a take-home midterm was listed in the syllabus, but about a week before the midterm, it was abruptly changed to an in-class midterm without proper notice or consent from the students. By the time grades were returned for that midterm, the deadline to take the class on a satisfactory/unsatisfactory basis or withdraw had already passed. Additional assignments were introduced after this deadline, and the final exam was no longer the sole examination, contrary to what was stated in the syllabus. The grading is stringent, with all assessments being written responses, and any deviation from the professor's expected answers can result in low or even zero scores, immediately impacting overall grades. Throughout the course, students do not have access to a visible grade book or platform like Canvas, making it challenging to track their progress as the syllabus and assignments continue to change unexpectedly. To perform well, memorizing terms from the assigned readings is essential, as outside information is often dismissed, and only definitions from the specified texts are accepted for full credit.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of eye-opening insights in this class. For example, I gained a vast understanding of the systemic hardships and inequities that Asian Americans have had to face in American history that is simply not talked about in American history. It was also very nice to have certain aspects of my own Asian American experience articulated, validating my experiences of racism and insecurity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course served as an introduction into the social construction of race and how that's played an important role in defining the history of all ethnic groups in the United States. Throughout the semester, we learned about the different laws, social norms, and cultural movements that contributed to the development and continuation of racism. Most importantly, the class discussed the effects of said racism, and explored how they've continued to ensure white supremacy in modernity. Another important factor covered was the concept of color-blind racism, which fundamentally argues that today's racism is maintained through subtle means that appear to uphold equality.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In Dr. Charmaine Royal's Race, Genomics, and Society course, I developed a deeper understanding of how race, though a social construct, significantly impacts scientific research and healthcare. I learned to critically evaluate the use of racial categories in genomic studies and how they can perpetuate harmful stereotypes rather than address health disparities. The course also emphasized the importance of open communication and respectful discussion, allowing me to listen to and consider different perspectives with an open mind. Additionally, I gained insights into how race intersects with other identities, such as gender and socioeconomic status, to shape health outcomes, reinforcing the need for culturally competent care. These lessons have fostered a socially conscious and ethical approach to addressing systemic inequities in science and healthcare.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my study skills and the ability to write under pressure (during the exams). Improved collaborative skills and how to facilitate empowering and respectful discussions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The specific science behind why race is not biological in humans, and the history of how race developed in America, and other countries. Also learned the impact socially defined race has on perceptions and life outcomes in America and different countries, such as Brazil.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The biggest take away from the class being that there is no biological race with the human race. The way in which we conceive race is a social construct based on a hierarchy. Humans are 99.6% genetically similar.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: participation, creative project documentary creation, and literature review

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I felt like this class was very lecture-based with not much writing, but our final project culminated in producing a documentary, which I learned useful skills from regarding collecting data, working with my discussion section/production team, and having conversations with people about very widely debated/misconceived ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about race as a social versus biological construct. Learned to think about the history of race and racism in a contextual and thorough way. Learned about genetics, intelligence and athletic ability.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel equipped with the tools and evidence to explain to others why race is not a biological concept. I have come to understand that lived experiences of individuals are shaped by genetic and environmental factors. Our final creative projects provided me with insight on how to facilitiate productive conversations about race, genomics, and society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This being a multidisciplinary course, we learned about many, many things. We learned the genetic basis of biological race (and the lack thereof in humans - i.e., we learned *why* humans don't have biological race); we learned about genetic ancestry, genomics, and so on; we learned about the social context of these scientific 'developments' (eugenics, profit, oppression, etc.); we learned about the fundamental theory of oppression.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the biological basis of race in humans, or lack thereof. I learned more about race, racial hierarchies, etc., in a global context. I learned about genetic testing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to separate biological and social concepts when looking at racial topics. I also understood the history behind what the modern understanding of race was. Finally, I found what it means to have different aspects of your identity and how that intersects with your biological makeup.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class provides an understanding of how scientific and genomic theories have contributed to the development of systemic racism. Discussions about historical events like Bacon's Rebellion, modern debates like race-based medicines such as BiDil, and about our understanding of race and racism and the factors informing it were incredibly engaging. The work we were doing felt important to learn about and discuss.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this class about how to work with a group, forming thoughts and structuring cohesive arguments, and the biological and social implications of race

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're considering taking Race, Genomics, and Society, I highly recommend it. This course offers a unique and thought-provoking perspective on how race intersects with science, especially genomics, and its implications for healthcare and society. Dr. Charmaine Royal fosters a respectful and open environment where you can engage in deep discussions, challenge assumptions, and explore the ethical dimensions of scientific research. The readings and case studies are compelling and relevant, pushing you to think critically about the role of race in shaping health outcomes and scientific practices. Additionally, the course includes distinguished guest speakers, providing valuable real-world perspectives. Be prepared to reflect, engage in meaningful conversations, and develop a more nuanced understanding of race and science. It’s a course that will not only broaden your knowledge but also inspire you to think differently about issues of social justice and equity.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
There are a lot of readings, and it is easy to fall behind. While the readings are discussed in class, if you don't necessarily get to all of them before class, you will probably be okay. Sometimes I found it more helpful to read or reread things after class gave me an overview of the topic they went in-depth on. 
Also, attendance and participation is technically mandatory, but there is a little wiggle room.  You can have 3 class absences and 2 discussion absences with no issue, and they seem to be somewhat lenient on participation; so long as you try to engage with the course, it will probably be okay.
This is a no-tech class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about breast cancer and how it is represented in various forms of art, such as paintings, photographs, journals, essays, poems, and other forms of writing. Beyond the topic, I was able to work on my writing skills, as we had multiple informal writings and formal writings throughout the semester, with ample feedback from Professor Lamm, so I could work on every piece of writing for the next one. I also improved my reading skills, pulling out the important parts of a piece and pulling out evidence to support it, and also my speaking skills as we did a lot of discussions in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

1) how to better analyze pieces of literature and artwork surrounding various themes of breast cancer, feminism, and intersectionality
2) the importance of representation and the various ways in which people's identities have historically been ignored, mocked, or silenced
3) a better understanding of the ways in which art and storytelling intersect and the way artists can infuse their works with important messages.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that the professor would send emails the day before each class reminding us of what we woudl be looking at the next day in class. This made it easy to figure out what readings/videos needed to be done before the class started the next year. I also liked the flipped classroom, as many thoughtful discussions and insights came from the professor allowing us to talk about the subject matter in class. I also loved the trip to the Nasher as it was another way to explore the themes and goals of the course reflected by an everyday example. I also liked that the papers were open-ended and allowed for the writer to reflect on their own experiences and pick the works we examined in class that most resonated with them. I would keep all of these elements for future years.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As previously mentioned, this class did not ask students to deeply reflect on the texts we read. Additionally, the professor's lectures tended to go onto tangents about completely unrelated topics and overgeneralized the Black experience. I remember the professor once asking the class, "Who runs the Black household?" Ignoring the fact that the class was majority non-Black, the professor assumed everyone would emphatically answer "women," but that assumes so much. What if your students don't have mothers? What if your students are from a multiracial household? There were so many moments when the professor made gendered generalizations of the Black experience, which always seemed to just be grounded in his own experience. These generalizations of women were often meant to be positive, but the professor's support of women almost always felt patronizing. And, when given the opportunity to really interrogate the gender parity and its psychosocial impact on Black women, there was nothing to be said.

response_text:
1. I learned how to analyze sources whilst deeply factoring in the author's background in order to truly understand their perspective on the matter.
2. I learned that capitalism is NOT inherent, but rather involved a lot of exploitation and integration within other systems that permitted its existence and flourishing.
3. I learned about the history of feudalism within Europe that preceded capitalism, and why this progression occurred in the first place.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed ways of connecting knowledge between the past and the present and attempted to apply complex economic and ethical theories to modern-day life. I also learned about the history of Capitalism, which has informed the way that I view the modern economic system, especially in the US. Finally, I learned about Marxism and Karl Marx's life which also provided me enough historical background to get a better understanding of capitalism as a system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My major is not related to history at all so there was a lot that I learned in this course that I was not introduced to before. After these discussions, I was able to get a clearer picture of the origins of capitalism and how our readings were tied together.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the skill of engaging with texts deeper through asking questions, taking in depth annotations, and making connections with other texts. This class has caused me to ask more questions when reading texts because of the historical claims the authors make pertaining to capitalism and labor. It is important to ask questions in order to increase understanding of the text. Additionally, I learned to take more in-depth annotations because of the semester project that requires students to analyze a text and explain its context, its value, and its views on labor and its laws. Additionally, there are certain terms in the class that are discussed in several texts, this has encouraged me to make comparisons among various texts in order to increase complex understanding.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would like to say that if you are a good writer and you are interested in history then this will definitely be an easy A for you. If you keep up with the course readings and you like to engage in a lot of group discussions, then I do believe that this course could be intellectually stimulating for you, however once you get behind, it is difficult to catch up. There are really only two assignments of the midterm and the final project. However be careful which project you pick because one definitely requires more personal investment than the other. Professor Shaharazard is a wonderful person and definitely brings some enthusiasm to class as she is very passionate about the topics in this course. However, the way she leads class can be all over the place, so if you are someone that appreciates a lot of structure in the classroom, attending this class can often feel like a waste of time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course developed and further enhanced my ability to read with context. If anything, it showed that using context is necessary for the full understanding of any political phenomenon. I learned to think more quantitatively in regards to presenting arguments. I also learned that Africa is a continent with a heart and a pulse unlike many others. To understand Africa, you must think with a whole different soul. And lastly, I learned that facts are not always enough in the fight to defend justice. Uncovering the truth is also very important. And that takes understanding languages and ways of life other than your own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a much deeper understanding of the African economy, especially how different regions are pursuing development in the face of structural and historical challenges. I also learned to think critically about the long-term impacts of colonialism and how it continues to shape political and economic systems today. Lastly, I gained insight into the richness and diversity of African cultures and how they intersect with global development narratives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned that sometimes problems facing a society aren't as straightforward as they may appear at face value. Prof Ebia taught us to analyze social issues through not only a comtemporary lens, but also a historical one inorder to better understand the root cause.
I also learned solutions to social problems should always take into account the particular needs of the specific peoples in question and not a one-size-fits-all approach
Through in-class debates and discussions, I improved my debating skills and how to present my arguments in a persuasive manner

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about development in Africa and leadership.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing I learned in this course is how development is not just about money or technology, it’s about power, history, and culture.Second, I learned to think critically about aid. Moyo’s “Dead Aid” made me question whether foreign help always helps. Sometimes, it creates dependency or supports corrupt governments. I now see that investment and local leadership may be more effective than traditional aid.Third, I learned how to analyze African development through different lenses colonial history, informal economies and religion. This course taught me to look beyond surface-level explanations and ask deeper questions about how and why development happens or doesn't happen.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the role of neoliberalization on the continent and the impact of aid both good and bad. I enjoyed that the professor gave a wide range of perspectives to allow us to form our own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really appreciated the focus on different kinds of aid and specific cases, this really helped me understand what was happening and gave examples of it to better understand its impacts. I think focusing on each kind of aid for a week or so really helped me understand the aid apparatus as a whole better as we found themes as we continued comparing different kinds of aid. I also liked learning about local context from when school fees came to sorgoun plants.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about the efforts to promote development in Africa, including failures and successes
2. I learned more about the field of cultural anthropology, especially in West Africa
3. I learned about local cultures in Africa and how effective development models will take into account these cultures/perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My writing a critical think skills greatly improved during the class. I gained a broader view of the work and not only learned about modern Africa but also colonial Africa. Overall, I feel like I came out of the course better able to analyze readings, write about topics that have many complications. I also became more aware to Africa which is an area of the world that I had not studied before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a new way of framing the African continent. Before this class, I thought aid was beneficial and helping the people on the continent. However, I have learned so much about better ways for the continent to develop and how history has caused the problem to be even larger. I also think the readings provided were amazing because they weren't reading I would have been able to find myself. I will even be using them in my senior thesis.

response_text: This course developed and further enhanced my ability to read with context. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Lastly, I gained insight into the richness and diversity of African cultures and how they intersect with global development narratives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing I learned in this course is how development is not just about money or technology, it’s about power, history, and culture.Second, I learned to think critically about aid. Moyo’s “Dead Aid” made me question whether foreign help always helps. Sometimes, it creates dependency or supports corrupt governments. I now see that investment and local leadership may be more effective than traditional aid.Third, I learned how to analyze African development through different lenses colonial history, informal economies and religion. This course taught me to look beyond surface-level explanations and ask deeper questions about how and why development happens or doesn't happen.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze the interconnectedness of history. This course starting with the American, then French, then Haitian, and lastly Latin American Revolutions offered a unique way to analyze history. As most courses tend to focus on one region, this course clearly displayed how ideas and movements travel across nations and waters. History always appeared segmented, but this history class displayed how universal forms of oppression and sentiments of freedom are. I additionally learned the power of history from below. Analyzing the writings and stories of often overlooked figures, it made it clear how distorted history really is as the predominant narrative encompassing history surrounds powerful white men. Reading about the impact of mostly unknown figures it displayed the overwhelming role of grassroots movements in inciting revolution.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course deepened my understanding of the Age of Revolutions as a global phenomenon, not just a series of isolated national events. I learned to connect political upheaval in France and Haiti with broader patterns of colonial resistance and empire. I developed a strong grasp of comparative historical analysis—especially in evaluating how race, class, and ideology shaped different revolutionary movements.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learnt how to develop my analytical skills, especially regarding primary sources.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the factors that caused the revolutions studied, how the average person in those locations contributed to them, and how they were all connected.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing I learned is that revolutions are never just about one moment, they build up over time and come from deeper tensions. I also got better at reading primary sources and thinking about what people were really trying to say or do. And I started seeing how different revolutions connect across the world, like how the Haitian and French ones influenced each other.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Knowledge: the causes and effects of the American, French, Haitian, and Latin American revolutions. More specifically, I learned details about them that many prior courses have failed to teach. I learned how they are interconnected. I learned how minority groups including women played a role in these revolutions. I learned a lot!
Methods: I learned to identify bias from an author based on their socio-economic-racial group. 
Ways of thinking: I learned that the answers to things are more complex than they seem. For example, it is not just enlightenment thought and bad monarchs that caused these revolutions (what is taught in most courses). there are so many more reasons and complexities which we covered in this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analyzing different perspectives, and critiquing authors/writers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about studying history with a bottom-up approach rather than a top-down approach. I learned about substantial overlap between Latin American revolutions and the American and French revolutions. I learned how to efficiently read and analyze scholarly sources.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about many figures involved in the age of revolutions. Before this class I didn't have much of an understanding of the history from below approach in these revolutions. I enjoyed learning about Toussaint Louverture and the Haitian revolution.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about different historiographical approaches to looking at this era of history ("history from above" and "history from below") and the merits and drawbacks of each. I also learned about historical events such as the Haitian Revolution and the Latin American wars of independence which I had limited knowledge about beforehand. Finally, I learned more about under-taught figures in American/French revolutionary history.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: One of the ways in which Professor Lamotte facilitated our learning is through a varied structure of class meetings. In any given class meeting, we had an opportunity to discuss the readings that we had covered for the week within small groups and then with the entire class; listen to a lecture from our professor; and present or hear a presentation over a topic that we discussed during lecture. Occasionally, we also had primary source workshops or a visit to the Rubenstein Library that would help fine-tune my ability to analyze primary sources. This structure allowed me to examine the topics we were learning about in several different ways and kept the atmosphere engaging.

Finally, if you are interested in learning more about whose stories are told and whose stories are silenced throughout history, as well as why, this class is a great one for you. Professor Lamotte is brilliant, high-energy, and a fantastic lecturer. You will not regret taking this course and will learn so much from the entire experience of being in this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Coming into the course I was completely unfamiliar with warfare- especially within the African context. Through taking Dr. Smith's course, I've learned about how war manifests and can change both the political and social landscape of a country. I've learned how to identify motivations for war and what characteristics allow it to exploit a country's most vulnerable populations. Furthermore, discussing topics such as rape as a weapon of war and the HIV/Aids outbreak across Africa has taught me about the importance of diction in how these issues are discussed and reported in the media. Overall, I've learned how to analyze the complexities of health and warfare in Africa outside of the narrow perspective that the media often portrays of the continent.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the world around me and specifically understand drivers of conflict and violence through the lense of marginalized populations such as queer communities, women, those of different ethnicities and races, immigrants, and more. In addition, learning how to read dense texts, ethnographies, and articles was a big part of the course, and I learned how to digest, understand, and analyse these texts as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a deeper understanding of the history of racialized and gendered medicine. I also learned how to evaluate medical/scientific interventions from a racially-conscious perspective and learned how to read texts better. Many of the people in the class are interested in pursuing healthcare professions so I think this class is particularly relevant and useful for us to critically evaluate the healthcare system and the how medicine has advanced through the expense of marginalized groups.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I understood how historical context and biopolitics contribute to modern healthcare implementations for all groups who don't fit the standard cis, white, male body type. Along with this, I learned about who the actors vs. the subjects were in many cases, and how racism is inherent in many medical practices we pursue today. (For example, I honestly had NO idea that black women slaves were the unwilling subjects who gave us the practice of gynecology we have today.) I also learned how to digest large readings and get the main takeaways as we discussed them during class. As a cis white woman, I do want to mention how I came into this class not having a ton of background on these subjects and I now have learned so much that I will apply in the medical field - like taking into account the history of practices, understanding how livelihoods and backgrounds should be considered, and understanding how my own biases could impact my work on any individual.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained insight into the feasibility and ethical responsibilities in conducting ethnographic research/ the obligations you have when discussing a group's history, specifics about the creation of medical specialties and the system of public health in the US overall, and a troubling of the solutions I had previously devised for how to fix the US healthcare system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed several key skills and insights. Firstly, I enhanced my writing skills, particularly in structuring arguments and presenting ideas effectively. Secondly, I gained a deeper understanding of South African history, culture, and socio-political issues, which broadened my global perspective. Lastly, participating in class discussions significantly improved my communication skills, as it required me to articulate my thoughts clearly, listen actively, and engage respectfully with diverse viewpoints.
