question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to understand history from a cause-and-effect lens, understanding the fundamental driving factors behind the fall of apartheid.I learned how to engage in conversations about a variety of topics I am uncomfortable with, and how to present a historical argument with feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Geography of South Africa
2. The nuance in the situation in Apartheid South Africa.
3. Role of religion is assessing what's moral and how its bent or not bend to feed a narrative or justify things.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the rise, the duration, and the fall of apartheid. I learned how to write different styles of essay (oped, reading review, memo, etc.).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a strong understanding of the variables that contributed to the apartheid state and its subsequent effects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We discussed various themes within the class. I learned about the system of apartheid as a whole, how it was upheld, the systems that were put in place to maintain power and control by the white minority, the ways in which the geography of the country played into the creation of apartheid, the role of the Afrikaner identity, and just an overall understanding of apartheid as a system that was upheld. We then discussed the dismantling of apartheid, the role other nations played in this Cold War story, the various movement groups such as the ANC, PAC, Black Consciousness Movement, etc, the important leadership at the time, and the way the state tried to use violence to maintain the system. Lastly, there was an understanding of the long-term effects of apartheid in creating the disparities that exist today, the TRC, and the economic impact.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Everything apartheid. Would take too long to list.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically consider the history of apartheid, appraising multiple resources and weighing them in a class setting. A key emphasis in this class was being able to articulate, and even be challenged, on certain takeaways and themes from the week's readings and videos.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I gained a thorough understanding of the mechanisms that drove apartheid in South Africa and the implications apartheid had on modern South Africa. 
- I also honed my ability to reason through knowledge and apply it during a classroom discussion, while defending my points and incorporating what my classmates had to say. 
- I also gained experience with writing papers, op-eds, memos, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Additionally I believe I gained very good reading comprehension skills. As a CS major reading is not the most common this to do in major-related classes and taking this course has allowed me to delve into readings and retain information way better.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lecturer's down-to-earth and approachable nature created a welcoming and supportive learning environment, which made it easier for students to engage with the material and seek help when needed. Additionally, the course's structure, which emphasized student input and active participation, was particularly effective. This approach fostered collaboration, encouraged diverse perspectives, and made the learning process more dynamic and engaging. These components—an approachable instructor and a participatory structure—are invaluable and should be retained in future iterations of the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was structured largely through discussion and clarification through asking questions. I loved this format because it allowed for engagement with a wide variety of sources pertaining to apartheid without being too reliant on a solid knowledge base early in the semester. The week by week themed format was also great because if you weren’t particularly interested in a topic, you only had to really focus on it for 1 week. Allowed for a lot of diversity of inquiry.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Shapiro was an incredible facilitator of my learning. Immensely knowledgeable and willing to push me on ideas, I felt like I had to bring my A game to every discussion and class period. I liked the incorporation of different modes of learning -- readings and videos -- and I found the discussions quite enriching.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the recap presentations that we did at the beginning of each class. They were a great way to synthesize what had been discussed the previous week, and also allowed me to see how other students were thinking about key themes and issues that arose throughout the course. I also loved the "What's Missing" assignment - I thought it was a great way to allow students some agency over the scope of a final assignment, and provided us with the opportunity to dive into a theme that we simply did not have time to cover in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of the class was phenomenal. I really enjoyed the roundtable-style discussions of the class and found them very intellectually stimulating. I really appreciated how Professor Shapiro made sure that everyone felt comfortable speaking while also giving little nudges to make sure that everyone spoke during the class--it ensured that we all participated equally. I would definitely recommend keeping the class to this small size and retaining the discussion-centric class model. I also enjoyed the online discussion posts that we created beforehand, which helped me plan out the points I wanted to make in class the next day.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked the discussion-based approach as we were able to delve into topics on Apartheid south Africa in a very unique way. The addition of weekly reviews led by students each week where great to refresh our minds on the previous topics we had covered and also served as a way to maintain certain ongoing topics beyond the class they were assigned to. The what's missing paper was also a great way to express our feelings of what could be a new topic that could be introduced to the class schedule and Dr. Shapiro made sure our ideas where heard of and discussed with the entire class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course, and dedicate the time to it. You will learn a lot, and fast, if you keep up with the readings (~100 pages per week) and participate in discussions. I came into the class with little knowledge of South African history, and I am walking away with an understanding of not only the events, but an ability to situate South African history in a broader African and global history. I was pushed to appraise my ideas more critically, and the writing standards are high. Getting an A is not easy in the class, but certainly woth the effort.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

There are many lessons to be taken from South Africa, and I think this course is worth taking regardless of your major or career goals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of things that I learned across this course and "South African Biographies and Autobiographies" was how to read very efficiently. The reading in this class has been about a book a week. When I first began learning with Prof. Shapiro, I would spend hours and hours on reading and it was difficult to have balance. As I matured in the class, I learned how to read a book within two hours, write reflections in response, and have a critical conversation with my classmates about it. This is a skill I really value. Thank you.I learned a lot about contemporary South Africa. I examined and thought about various themes such as employment, what democracy means, popular engagement, etc. It's required me to think critically about a society I haven't existed within, which was an interesting experience.I also learned how to build a curriculum. In our "What's Missing" paper, Prof. Shapiro asked us to add a theme to our coursework. This made me think about what sources and discussion questions would make for an enlightening and interesting class. I thought that becoming the professor, in a way, was cool.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I've learned to thinking globally about environmental issues. For an effective global environmental justice movement, it is important to have the following components: multilingual, multicultural, intergenerational, interracial, and spiritual. There are many injustices entangled with exploitative capitalistic systems, yet we cannot divorce ourselves from capital.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Lots of insights into current environmental and social issues throughout the world that I had not previously heard about; New ways of looking at environmental justice from discussions of civil rights, indigenous communities, and political happenings; Wisdom from an expert (Dr. Chavis) in the field of social change.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to evaluate different environmental justice issues through different contexts but the same lens, developed a deep appreciation that it's our job as humanity to interact with the earth appropriately and respectfully, and that most of our problems come from a capitlistic mindset, and that the a huge part of getting to where we need to be is through changing that mindset through education and one person at a time

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a deep understanding of the Principles of Environmental Justice, I learned my classmates' perspectives on various issues around EJ, and I learned about the importance of having a Global Environmental Justice Center at Duke in the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class allowed me to develope a perspective on Enviromental Justice- a concept that had hardly been introduced to me before. I am able to analyze cases of enviromental justice/injustice and come to conclusions and possibly brainsotrm solutions. Most importantly, this class has brought to me awareness: I need to think about the proportion of enviromental imapcts on specific communities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely developed skills in analyzing environmental justice based on the 17 principles of environmental justice. I thought the case studies we did were also very helpful in getting deep knowledge on various countries. The dangers of being a Colombian activist were an especially eye-opening topic. The effectiveness of Botswanan government in empowering sustainable development was another one. I especially enjoyed learning from the Brazilian activists Dr. Chavis brought in, as they shared important insights on women's role in leading change movements. Because women are traditionally caretakers, they've played an especially important role driving community-oriented activism in Brazil's favelas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - I wo;uld like to say my focus was primarily on themes of humanism, identity, and racial capital. Each of these themes are directly connected to one another and approach the idea of the black radical tradition in various ways. For humanism, we spent the course reading Fanon, Robinson, Wilderson and other black intellectual thinkers who are redefining what it means to be and exist outside the concept of being human. This directly leads to our understanding of how this would affect idenity, as if one is not even considered to be human or considered to be lesser than human, their would be a sort of inferiority complex or psychological notion of subjugation that would become instilled in a community. Thus, the ideas surrounding racial capital come into the foray, for in order to further advance the rather insatiable hunger of capitalism and its systems, a form of racial order or hierarchy only benefits profit and labor. This course helped me in connecting some of these ideas effectively and providing thoughtful analysis when bringing together these subjects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned different framing of the Black radical tradition.
I learned insights into black critical theory from a non-US perspective as well as a non-male perspective.
I learned alternative views of capitalism and its effects on people of color.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was very helpful in learning more about a Black anthropological canon and methods. Three things I learned were: different kinds of applicable methods in the discipline, like mapping, embodied ethnography, and fiction writing; career paths for anthropology PhDs outside of academia and how these scholars write accessibly for different audiences; and finally, I was able to do a creative, non-traditional final project that helped me formulate my dissertation research interests.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I gained a good definition of what ethnography is as well as the varying modes and methods with which people use to engage ethnography, including visual, digital, and performance aspects. As such, I'm thinking more about the modes and methods I engage with as it relates to my doctoral project. I also developed skills as it relates to engaging with and creating connections across materials.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

1. I learnt why intellectual biographies are important aspects of understanding key anthropological networks. This is a learning strategy I implemented in all my other classes and will continue doing so in the future. 
2. I learnt the MANY different ways of ethnographic methodology - visual, ethnographic film, performance, poetry, essay, digital. All of which is very useful as a grad student currently engaged in ethnographic field methods.
3. I absolutely loved the syllabus of the class. The class flowed so well and the final paper for the class let us make the paper useful for us as scholars. I will keep in mind this syllabus when it is my time to create a syllabus too.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my understanding of archives and the different mediums in which they can exist. I learned about important Black authors, photographers, and musicians that have shaped black consciousness through their work both in the United States and across Africa.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I believe this course was huge in developing my ways of engaging with archival theory. I've learned about Black art and the archive, Black aquatic archive theory, and I learned a generous amount from my classmates through the seminar format.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: While in this course, I learned to expand my perspective on the scope of archival materials. Because of the engagement with the readings, I now value the body as an archive. I also understand that archives possess the ability to dialogue. Most importantly, I gained a significant reading list and resources to support my arguments and theories that I would not have been aware of if it weren't for this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think about and narrate Black archival practice expansively (but also the importance of considering the consequences/perils of the impulse to recollect everything); How to think more critically about waterscapes as archives, and as liberatory spaces beyond how they've been narrated historically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Interpreting Archival Silence: This course deepened my understanding of how historical erasure operates and how silences in the archive are not accidental but structured. I learned to “read between the lines” and to think critically about whose stories are told—and whose are not.
Creative Engagement with Archival Material: Through our exposure to artists, writers, and scholars who use the archive as both material and metaphor, I developed new ways of thinking about memory, storytelling, and resistance. The course showed me how archives can be reimagined through poetry, performance, and visual art.
Diasporic and Transnational Thinking: I learned to think across geographies and histories—connecting the Black experience in the U.S., South Africa, and other parts of the diaspora. The course challenged me to think about the global entanglements of anti-Blackness and creative survival.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As someone who doesn't work a ton with theoretical frameworks and someone new to archiving, this was a great way for me to expand my own ideas of what an archive is and what the archive has the potential to be. Specifically in terms of the Black archive, I  have the following takeaways from the course1) Theoretical frameworks for archiving: In this course I  learned about the theoretical frameworks about the different forms of archiving. With each of the readings, I was introduced to a new idea or theory about the Black archive.2) redefining my ideas of the Black archive: this course really expanded my thinking about what an archive could be. I  enjoyed how we looked at different forms of archiving such as film, photography, and even forms of non-materiality like the ocean.3) interdisciplinary archival methods: I  really enjoyed this interdisciplinary class. We had people from various disciplines that added to the strength of the discussion.This allowed me to think through other ways that people think about emobidment and archiving outside of the traditional literary forms that I  am used to observing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot more about African countries and traditions, alternative ways of thinking about the archive, and how to write critically in response to archival theory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The archival visits to the Schomburg and Rubenstein which were framed by the theoretical texts we read throughout the course was enlightening and helped me to perceive the immensity of what it was to imagine the black body through these analytical tools. This coupled with the alternative forms of archival memory (photography, play writing, filmmaking, etc.) will definitely be useful in my disseration writing. 
Second, the guest speakers we periodically had in class helped to engage the class with the texts beyond surface-level analysis. We were able to tailor our questions or responses to the creator of said texts, rather than spending time on speculating possibilities of textual analysis. I found this interview style of class to be highly beneficial to my appreciation of what we were learning, and it further birthed analytical queries as to what the text entailed. 
Finally, hearing the responses from my classmates as to their analysis of what had been covered that week was beneficial to my understanding of the text, and helped me to think through the class in a fulfilling manner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First of all, this course introduced me to archival work in the practical, applied definition of the term. I was essentially going in blind although with the understanding that the archival process was (and is) front and center in my research and scholarly aspirations more generally. Our trip to the Schomburg Center,  as well as to the Rubenstein on a couple of occasions, really cultivated the feeling and process of archival practice from its most rudimentary to much more complex forms. In other words, the practical skills and methods referring to everything form applying for research profiles at the Schomburg to using finding aids to search for materials and beyond were all nurtured  by and through this course. But things do not just stop there. The theoretical knowledge gained in this course has been so vast that it would be nearly impossible to isolate one or two specific insights. I would say that this course cultivated a specific reading practice in me, which I intend to retain as I progress through my studies. Thinking archivally, and, specifically, thinking about the use of archival materials as forms of evidence, their placement in the texts we studied, the rhetorics built around them, and so forth, made me consistently consider the ethics of using the archives – especially those which such traumatic, heavy, or otherwise violence-laden sources. Although I certainly have room to improve, I feel like this course really required me to read closer than ever; to probe not only the arguments being presented, but also to scrutinize the archival sources being cited – often even trying to locate primary sources in order to compare and contextualize how certain citation were being implemented. Sometimes my discoveries were shocking with regard to certain decontextualized or otherwise heavily manipulated usages of primary material. In any case, I consider this a skill or even a reading method that I hope to transfer into my scholarship hence forth. Lastly, I have to mention the community of research fostered by this course. Through this course I have established working, collaborative friendships which I hope will persist. In my field, the caricature of the private, hermetic scholar still remains the more or less hegemonic image of what scholarship is or ought to be. This course absolutely challenged this image, and did so furthermore without resorting to the sorts of romanticized communities you often hear about in higher education. In a very material, working, and concrete sense, this class produced and actualized a real research community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Methods to engage and understand archival material. An expansion of what I conceive of as "the archive".  The importance of historiography and the difficulties Black people have faced in preserving their past experiences.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the seminar aspect of the course. Discussing the material with my peers was very helpful and allowed me to gain from their perspectives. I also enjoyed the guest speakers and learning about their work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was mainly seminar/discussion based after a week of reading and a reflection. I don't always enjoy when classes use repetitive methods of entering into the material, however, I believe that Khwezi and Chris are great facilitators and interject/guide the conversation so that the class time is fruitful for the participants.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would keep the guest visits a part of the course. Speaking with scholars exploring these topics and uncovering archives in such a powerful way has helped me form my methodologies and thesis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes! I definitely appreciate the option to do a creative project with accompanying writing and I think future students would also find this useful. I also liked how we focused on different categories of archives over the course of the semester (periodicals and print media, photographs, waterscapes, etc)—this gave breadth to an understanding of what an archive is and how they can function.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The balance between theory and creative expression made the course incredibly rich. The readings, while challenging at times, were thoughtfully curated and gave us a solid foundation for discussion. The Schomburg trip was an unforgettable experience—it grounded the theoretical in the tangible and emotional. I would definitely keep that as part of the course in future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors facilitated our learning through the formats of readings, written reflections, and trips to various archives. I  found each of these to be formative to my own personal experience in the course. With the reflections, I was able to express my own thoughts about the reading and generate ideas about the Black archive in formative ways. The trips to the archives allowed me to gain experience with handling written materials. Personally, I  enjoyed each of these components and found them to be useful for my own research and personal understandings of the archive.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class is discussion-based and relies heavily on the readings to facilitate these discussions. Additionally, the professors brought in some guest lecturers for some classes, and we were able to take a trip to the Schomburg library in New York City. I really enjoyed all the parts of the class! I liked how the readings included both classics in Black archival thought and some emerging research and artworks. These ideas were all new to me, even though I had taken classes about archives before. I suppose those focused more on literature by white people. However, these readings were all engaging and expanded my worldview a lot. The guest lecturers were all super nice in answering all of our questions and giving overviews of their work, which helped a lot in imagining how archival research can manifest in different genres of art. The trip to the Schomburg was also incredibly special. I had never been to Harlem before, and it was wonderful to see how Black thought and art could have really grown in times like the Harlem Renaissance. The Schomburg as a library was also really unique, and I felt lucky to have experienced it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The integration of guest speakers, physical place analysis, as well as archival research was important to my overall learning experience and enhanced my overall academic insight. In the future as an instructor, emphasis on embodied learning will definitely be crucial to my pedagogy.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The basic format of the course (weekly reading with discussion) was enhanced with frequent guest speakers and trips to the Rubenstein, and, of course, our Schomburg excursion. I'll keep it simply by saying that all of the above should be kept in forthcoming iterations of the course. The addition of public lectures and events was also very successful, as it not only augmented the learning environment and our grasp of course material, but it also allowed us to interact on a quite intimate level with invited scholars and other experts. This as well is, I think, worth retaining. I also always appreciated and found extremely useful Chris and Khwezi's insights and (let's call them, casual or impromptu) lectures. They clearly wanted to cultivate a discussion based classroom, and thus their input was not lecture heavy. Instead, their insights were laced and interwoven into the overall class discussion, which was to the benefit of the learning environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my understanding of archives and the different mediums in which they can exist. I learned about important Black authors, photographers, and musicians that have shaped black consciousness through their work both in the United States and across Africa.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I believe this course was huge in developing my ways of engaging with archival theory. I've learned about Black art and the archive, Black aquatic archive theory, and I learned a generous amount from my classmates through the seminar format.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: While in this course, I learned to expand my perspective on the scope of archival materials. Because of the engagement with the readings, I now value the body as an archive. I also understand that archives possess the ability to dialogue. Most importantly, I gained a significant reading list and resources to support my arguments and theories that I would not have been aware of if it weren't for this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think about and narrate Black archival practice expansively (but also the importance of considering the consequences/perils of the impulse to recollect everything); How to think more critically about waterscapes as archives, and as liberatory spaces beyond how they've been narrated historically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Interpreting Archival Silence: This course deepened my understanding of how historical erasure operates and how silences in the archive are not accidental but structured. I learned to “read between the lines” and to think critically about whose stories are told—and whose are not.
Creative Engagement with Archival Material: Through our exposure to artists, writers, and scholars who use the archive as both material and metaphor, I developed new ways of thinking about memory, storytelling, and resistance. The course showed me how archives can be reimagined through poetry, performance, and visual art.
Diasporic and Transnational Thinking: I learned to think across geographies and histories—connecting the Black experience in the U.S., South Africa, and other parts of the diaspora. The course challenged me to think about the global entanglements of anti-Blackness and creative survival.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As someone who doesn't work a ton with theoretical frameworks and someone new to archiving, this was a great way for me to expand my own ideas of what an archive is and what the archive has the potential to be. Specifically in terms of the Black archive, I  have the following takeaways from the course1) Theoretical frameworks for archiving: In this course I  learned about the theoretical frameworks about the different forms of archiving. With each of the readings, I was introduced to a new idea or theory about the Black archive.2) redefining my ideas of the Black archive: this course really expanded my thinking about what an archive could be. I  enjoyed how we looked at different forms of archiving such as film, photography, and even forms of non-materiality like the ocean.3) interdisciplinary archival methods: I  really enjoyed this interdisciplinary class. We had people from various disciplines that added to the strength of the discussion.This allowed me to think through other ways that people think about emobidment and archiving outside of the traditional literary forms that I  am used to observing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot more about African countries and traditions, alternative ways of thinking about the archive, and how to write critically in response to archival theory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The archival visits to the Schomburg and Rubenstein which were framed by the theoretical texts we read throughout the course was enlightening and helped me to perceive the immensity of what it was to imagine the black body through these analytical tools. This coupled with the alternative forms of archival memory (photography, play writing, filmmaking, etc.) will definitely be useful in my disseration writing. 
Second, the guest speakers we periodically had in class helped to engage the class with the texts beyond surface-level analysis. We were able to tailor our questions or responses to the creator of said texts, rather than spending time on speculating possibilities of textual analysis. I found this interview style of class to be highly beneficial to my appreciation of what we were learning, and it further birthed analytical queries as to what the text entailed. 
Finally, hearing the responses from my classmates as to their analysis of what had been covered that week was beneficial to my understanding of the text, and helped me to think through the class in a fulfilling manner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First of all, this course introduced me to archival work in the practical, applied definition of the term. I was essentially going in blind although with the understanding that the archival process was (and is) front and center in my research and scholarly aspirations more generally. Our trip to the Schomburg Center,  as well as to the Rubenstein on a couple of occasions, really cultivated the feeling and process of archival practice from its most rudimentary to much more complex forms. In other words, the practical skills and methods referring to everything form applying for research profiles at the Schomburg to using finding aids to search for materials and beyond were all nurtured  by and through this course. But things do not just stop there. The theoretical knowledge gained in this course has been so vast that it would be nearly impossible to isolate one or two specific insights. I would say that this course cultivated a specific reading practice in me, which I intend to retain as I progress through my studies. Thinking archivally, and, specifically, thinking about the use of archival materials as forms of evidence, their placement in the texts we studied, the rhetorics built around them, and so forth, made me consistently consider the ethics of using the archives – especially those which such traumatic, heavy, or otherwise violence-laden sources. Although I certainly have room to improve, I feel like this course really required me to read closer than ever; to probe not only the arguments being presented, but also to scrutinize the archival sources being cited – often even trying to locate primary sources in order to compare and contextualize how certain citation were being implemented. Sometimes my discoveries were shocking with regard to certain decontextualized or otherwise heavily manipulated usages of primary material. In any case, I consider this a skill or even a reading method that I hope to transfer into my scholarship hence forth. Lastly, I have to mention the community of research fostered by this course. Through this course I have established working, collaborative friendships which I hope will persist. In my field, the caricature of the private, hermetic scholar still remains the more or less hegemonic image of what scholarship is or ought to be. This course absolutely challenged this image, and did so furthermore without resorting to the sorts of romanticized communities you often hear about in higher education. In a very material, working, and concrete sense, this class produced and actualized a real research community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Methods to engage and understand archival material. An expansion of what I conceive of as "the archive".  The importance of historiography and the difficulties Black people have faced in preserving their past experiences.

response_text: In this course, I learned more about existentialism and nihilism. Those were concepts I wasn't familiar with coming into the course. I really appreciated the was that Professor Winters paired traditional existential readings with those that engaged gender, race, and class in different ways. I was also encouraged to think about the ways other scholars engage with themes from existentialism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to use intertextuality to talk about contemporary southern literature and how it relates to many themes in race, identity and socio-economic issues still present today. I learned about unique African-American experiences  and the concept of the "Dirty South" as it relates to OutKast.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct critical analyses of contemporary literature, understanding the nuanced conversations about race and socioeconomic class in grappling with oppression and unjust systems. I also learned how to facilitate and engage in discussions with peers to analyze difficult passages and collectively understand its deeper meaning. I also learned how to discuss contemporary media like Beyoncé's visual album and Outkast's music in an academic setting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The first method I developed and strengthened in the course was the ability to think critically and to revise, the second was asking important questions about the text, and the third was engaging in a group discussion for long periods of time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was one of the most unique courses I have taken so far at Duke. The largest skill I've learned throughout this course is to deeply engage with literary works. This course teaches you how to critically analyze themes and meanings that may not be obvious on the surface. This course has taught me how to question literature and how to interpret what the author is trying to express.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I came into the class as someone who did not enjoy thinking about things on a deeper level, especially when it concerned issues I felt I did not have a control over. In this class we talked about issues in the Southern African American society, ranging from culture, slavery, to hip hop. This class taught me how to have academic discussions on issues and learn how to analyze content more critically and effectively. I have found myself not only a better speaker, but more able to form critical arguments and discussion points on the spot.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I absolutely loved this course and the opportunity to engage with contemporary literature and media to further my ability to analyze and reason about systemic racism and collective healing. The engaging readings were so fun to read, and weekly blog posts were great to keep us accountable in completing readings on time. I loved doing our individual and group presentations to better digest the course materials and form my own understanding of prominent themes. I think the structure of the course worked great! Professor McInnis was so knowledgeable and kind, and was very encouraging for students to share our thoughts in class and experiment. He always brought a lot of excitement but also thoughtfulness to class, which I loved.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor engaged all of the students and was extremely open to ideas posed by students. Almost always, professors will correct students if they are wrong about something, but professor McInnis was open to any and every idea proposed by students, and he took them and used them for the benefit of class discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor McInnis is one of the most passionate professors or teachers I have ever had. I've never met someone as enthusiastic to teach their content to a group of students. Professor McInnis truly cares about what is taught in class and the deep topics that we are analyzing. What made this course so amazing and fascinating was Professor McInnis. Each day, he would show up to class with enthusiasm to go over class readings. Professor McInnis was so knowledgeable about his field that I would often stay after class to ask him about specific passages or unique real world applications of what we go over in class, and he would always take the time to answer my questions thoroughly.Lastly, Professor McInnis would always make sure to find time to meet with me for office hours outside of class if I needed it. There are very few professors who would meet at 6:00 PM on a Friday to answer a students questions. It truly shows how much Professor McInnis cares about his students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was a very respectful and welcoming environment. Everyone participated and all of were engaged in the conversations. Something I liked about Professor McInnis was how he facilitated discussions. There would be times where no one would know what to say and he would be able to ask questions or direct us towards a better discussion. For example, when we were supposed to be discussing an experimental text by Randall Kenan, no one said anything because we were all confused by the structure of the reading. He was able to give us a good explanation and change the format of his questions to help us have a good discussion.

response_text: This is an example of a college course that I will always remember. I often hear the saying that college is a time to learn about things that you will never have the opportunity to learn about again. In 20 years, I can always pick up a textbook and learn about mathematical concepts or chemistry, but I will never again get to sit in a room and discuss such important topics that affect society. This class changes the way that you think about the world around you. It allows you to see aspects of society that you would never notice on the surface.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: My biggest advice to a future student would be to really embrace what this course has to offer. Take the time to read every assigned reading thoroughly(even the optional ones). Each reading has a unique message or purpose. Secondly, don't be afraid to take a risk in discussion or writing and don't be afraid to question. On the blog posts, it can seem tempting to write about a surface level theme, but try to dig deeper and explore a complex theme. Professor McInnis loves when students have a unique perspective on a reading.Lastly, and maybe most importantly, get to know Professor McInnis. By getting to know Professor McInnis, you start to see how truly passionate he is about his work and his courses. When I flunched Professor McInnis, I got to ask all about his career and research. I got to see how knowledgeable he is in his field and how much he cares about what he teaches. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about many important foundational elements of African diasporic performance genres, including but not limited to call-and-response and polyrhythms. 
I learned about the ways in which corporeal knowledge is embedded in various performance genres and contains important meanings of identity, cultural preservation, and resistance in the African diaspora. 
Finally, I learned about how various African diasporic performance genres have been co-opted, discredited, and misappropriated by white society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The rooted ways that race impacts someone's experience with the medical field.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned to look at situations from multiple perspectives 
2) I learned to question why our systems are structured the way they are
3) I learned how to analyze different sources

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned new ways of viewing the world and combatting bias.
1) The effect of racism and disease narratives on the world in the past and present.
2) The way disease has been used as a weapon.
3) How to discuss bias while avoiding bias.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the world around me and specifically understand drivers of conflict and violence through the lense of marginalized populations such as queer communities, women, those of different ethnicities and races, immigrants, and more. In addition, learning how to read dense texts, ethnographies, and articles was a big part of the course, and I learned how to digest, understand, and analyse these texts as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a deeper understanding of the history of racialized and gendered medicine. I also learned how to evaluate medical/scientific interventions from a racially-conscious perspective and learned how to read texts better. Many of the people in the class are interested in pursuing healthcare professions so I think this class is particularly relevant and useful for us to critically evaluate the healthcare system and the how medicine has advanced through the expense of marginalized groups.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I understood how historical context and biopolitics contribute to modern healthcare implementations for all groups who don't fit the standard cis, white, male body type. Along with this, I learned about who the actors vs. the subjects were in many cases, and how racism is inherent in many medical practices we pursue today. (For example, I honestly had NO idea that black women slaves were the unwilling subjects who gave us the practice of gynecology we have today.) I also learned how to digest large readings and get the main takeaways as we discussed them during class. As a cis white woman, I do want to mention how I came into this class not having a ton of background on these subjects and I now have learned so much that I will apply in the medical field - like taking into account the history of practices, understanding how livelihoods and backgrounds should be considered, and understanding how my own biases could impact my work on any individual.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to engage in seminar/discussion based learning. The class is also reading heavy (~150 pages a week), but it only met once so it was doable. I learned a lot about colonial legacies in healthcare

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained insight into the feasibility and ethical responsibilities in conducting ethnographic research/ the obligations you have when discussing a group's history, specifics about the creation of medical specialties and the system of public health in the US overall, and a troubling of the solutions I had previously devised for how to fix the US healthcare system.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the one book a week format. It was a lot of material but that allowed for a lot of depth and breadth, which I think is essential for these types of rooted and sensitive topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Rogers is an incredible human being who has a deep passion for global health and anthropology and other social science studies as well. Writing on the board to elucidate certain concepts that came about in our discussions to sharing stories of authors or other professors she interacted with, and even bringing current events into histories we were learning about facilitated my learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the seminar, discussion-based nature of the class. I also really enjoyed the student-led discussions because it helps students engage more deeply in the text, especially those who are leading the discussion. I also like the fact that it was longer (2.5 hrs) and once a week because you really need that amount of uninterrupted time to engage in such heavy texts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was the first time this class was taught, and while there were some bumps in the road, the professor did an AMAZING job with getting us to hear a diverse range of case studies and racial perspectives that allowed us to dive deep and "get real" with the concepts at play. This class felt pretty linear in the ways you'd want a class to be linear - like having a great direction with the texts we were made to read each week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Rogers was really good! She's super nice and approachable, and has a lot of interesting things to add about the reading content. She is also very flexible in terms of what we choose to discuss/what parts of the reading we focus on.

I learned very little. 
Lectures in this course were quite poor when Dr. Piot was at the wheel, the most useful parts of this course were:

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
In this course, I discovered that money is far more than just currency, it’s a cultural force. I learned that money carries deep symbolic meaning, varying across societies. For example, while dollars might seem neutral to me, other communities use shells, cattle, or digital tokens, each reflecting unique values. This shifted my perspective: money isn’t just about economics; it’s about people’s beliefs and social ties.
Finally, I explored money’s role in power structures. From colonial histories to modern cryptocurrencies, I saw how monetary systems enforce or challenge inequality. This course taught me to question assumptions—like the myth of barter, and analyze money as a tool of social control. Now, I see every transaction as part of a larger cultural story.

response_text: I really enjoyed the learning environment of this class. I enjoy a lecture-style class, and it was a bit of an adjustment but I ended up enjoying the no-slides style of the class and how the professor just talks and we listen and take notes. I like how Dr. Piot is very open to hearing from students in the class regarding our readings and also to provide their knowledge on some o the topics we were discussing. As someone who is less familiar with econ and anthropology, this allowed for me to be able to sit back and listen and learn which I really appreciated. I enjoyed the course components as well - although the readings could be dense and sometimes difficult to parse out, the fact that we would go through them in class and highlight the important information was very helpful. The 2 papers were also great, with clear instructions, and could be easily completed with the information we learned in class. The two exams were as expected (well the first at least, we haven't taken the second yet) and not anything too surprising.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this course. I found it to be super interesting and it made me think about money in ways that I never had before. The workload was very light. Each week there would be assigned readings. You don't even have to read them because Professor Piot dives deep enough into them during class which I appreciated. Our grade was made up of 2 essays and 2 exams. The essay topics were very fun to write about. I would recommend going to office hours before writing them. The TAs are extremely helpful and you can ask them literally anything. They also tell you exactly what they are looking for in the essay. The exams were good too. The way to do well on them is to go to every class (though attendance isn't required) and just write down everything that is said. If you understand your notes and read them before the test, you will do well. The test consisted of true/false questions to start and then a bunch of short answer questions. A lot of people didn't do well on the true/false section so they ended up curving that part. Overall, the course was really cool and you learn a lot about money, even though you would think you know everything about it given how common it is.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Different perspectives on and approaches to ethnography, as well as the challenges of doing it (in the "field" and in writing).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was very helpful in learning more about a Black anthropological canon and methods. Three things I learned were: different kinds of applicable methods in the discipline, like mapping, embodied ethnography, and fiction writing; career paths for anthropology PhDs outside of academia and how these scholars write accessibly for different audiences; and finally, I was able to do a creative, non-traditional final project that helped me formulate my dissertation research interests.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Think of different ways that ethnography is both output and method and of different ethnographic methodologies.
How popular culture can be read ethnographically.
Connections with other academics are important to know and develop.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course invite me to expand my understanding of what it means to do ethnography, especially as it relates to Black ethnographers. I gained a good definition of what ethnography is as well as the varying modes and methods with which people use to engage ethnography, including visual, digital, and performance aspects. As such, I'm thinking more about the modes and methods I engage with as it relates to my doctoral project. I also developed skills as it relates to engaging with and creating connections across materials.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learnt why intellectual biographies are important aspects of understanding key anthropological networks. This is a learning strategy I implemented in all my other classes and will continue doing so in the future. 
2. I learnt the MANY different ways of ethnographic methodology - visual, ethnographic film, performance, poetry, essay, digital. All of which is very useful as a grad student currently engaged in ethnographic field methods.
3. I absolutely loved the syllabus of the class. The class flowed so well and the final paper for the class let us make the paper useful for us as scholars. I will keep in mind this syllabus when it is my time to create a syllabus too.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciate the different media we engaged with in the class! They were engaging and effective at communicating the breadth of ethnography.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Tracie is a caring and attentive teacher who creates a positive and warm space of learning and dialogue. I like that Tracie always includes a poem/song to start the class, and lets the class lead converastion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor always provided a list of questions from the readings for us to discuss. As well as putting up key quotes from the readings. A very interesting component of the class was to consider the intellectual biographies of the authors we were reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: It was great to be able to engage with the many writer and scholars we engage with throughout the course. It was helpful to see the different ways that scholars could address similar themes. I also like the use of articles and book chapters rather than reading entire books. I found it easier to get engaged with and follow the readings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The intellectual bios, using a multi-modal style of teaching ethnographic methods and the ways in which Professor Canada made the class safe to discuss our own positionalities with regard to our own anthropological careers was immensely valuable to me and certainly something I want to borrow for my own teaching career.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was fantastic! It's not lost on me how much Prof. Canada labored to care for us as a seminar, and invited us to do the same for one another. From the construction of the syllabus to getting feedback midway through the semester to the feedback you left on our submissions, thank you! These acts of care made it possible for us to rigorously engage with the material of the class, and our learning was all the better for it. I also appreciate that you'd tell us how you decided on the syllabus and how you were thinking about the course as a whole; super helpful for future educators!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating with a wide range of anthropologists working in different areas/on topics that often had similar theoretical concerns, but distinct methods or approaches. Unlike most grad classes, which are usually about the instructor's highly specialized knowledge, this class was helpful for introducing students to a broad range of thinkers and anthropologists...and for many anthropologists who might never learn about Black studies or Black feminist theory I think this is a great class to offer.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: A variety of approaches, objects of study and connections to content that was outside academia.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Canada really created a classroom environment where everyone felt willing to share as we wrestled with both the course materials as well as our own projects and positionality within the academy. Professor Canada was willing to welcome our questions and help us think through things we may be struggling with.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed critical skills for analyzing visual and written media, particularly in how they address themes of race, history, and identity, as seen in Lovecraft Country. By studying the show alongside academic articles, I learned to connect fictional narratives with real-world social issues, such as systemic racism, historical erasure, and cultural resilience. The course improved my ability to synthesize insights from diverse texts and craft arguments that bridge media content with academic research.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tracie Canada created an engaging and inclusive learning environment by blending visual storytelling with academic readings. The structure of alternating between watching Lovecraft Country and reading scholarly articles provided a dynamic way to understand complex themes. Analyzing Lovecraft Country alongside academic readings made the material both accessible and thought-provoking. Class discussions were essential for unpacking layered themes and allowed for collaborative learning. Assignments like comparing media themes with historical and cultural realities helped deepen my understanding.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The only thing that I learned in this course, was to never take a class taught by Tim Tyson again. While Professor Williams was lovely and kind. Tim Tyson was arrogant, condescending, and the exact opposite of what I would expect to see in a member of Duke Faculty. To start, he went on an anti semetic rant in class where he said "no one talks about jew power, but they quietly have power through the banking industry". While I am not jewish, to see this behavior from a member of such a prestigious university was disgusting. One of my friends in the class is Jewish, and the fact that he had to sit and listen to professor Tysons' ridiculous comments were insane. I also feel very afraid to take action regarding these comments, because Tyson has been extremely vindictive throughout the semester. For example, the majority of the class got an extremely poor grade on the midterm. Instead of trying to help students improve, he said "if I had taken the test I would have gotten a 100". I was one of the fortunate few students who got a B (most got a C, D, or F) however he still refused to respond to an email I sent asking him for help in the class. I hope that there is some training given to Tyson in the future to fix his anti semetic and belittling behavior.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Not much, the professor was incredibly disorganized. The syllabus wasn't even on Sakai or Canvas, was on random website on safari. Dr. Tyson would just stand there from 6:30 to 9:30 and just talk, as slow and long as possible. He is not of the age to be a lecturer any more in my opinion. Every student in class would sit there on their computer for 2.5 hrs and do other hw or scroll on their computer. This was due to the fact that all he did was stand there, it was incredibly boring and unfair to students. No attempt to change anything. He is a historian and New York Times bestseller and this is what he does, but doesnt mean it will work as a teacher.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Aside from Tysons awful statements in class, the class was structured horribly. On the first day of class Tyson stated that we would have hard conversations that would help us grow. Not a single real conversation about racial relations in the south happened in this class. Instead, each week Tyson would get up there and ramble for the first 90 minutes of class. He is one of the least engaging speakers I have ever listened to. The only reprieve the class would have from Tysons rambling was when professor Williams would get up and sing. Her singing was amazing and was the only positive of each class. When it comes to the readings, Tyson assigned multiple expensive books that he wrote himself. I know that this is common for most professors, however it was extremely frustrating because the books were no different than what he discussed in class. Additionally his two most popular books have been discredited with his Emmitt Till Book being described in one news article as "Tysons Tall Tales". I have no problem paying for a book that will enhance my learning. However, when the book is filled with lies made up by a professor who does not care about his students I have a problem purchasing them.
