course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Nothing it was horrendous. All my classmates agree. Yes the subject matter was important and strong but the teaching was terrible. Never engaged us. On exam, they did not tell us how they would grade and gave us very broad instructions and then failed most of us because they said we didn't read but they never said it was a reading quiz. Just an exam and given 15 terms so everyone studied by looking them up and he graded so harshly. The other lady who lectured did not make much sense at all and would read from typed out transcript never from her own thoughts.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was not at all intellectually stimulating. Professor Tyson made this clear when he fell asleep on three occasions during the semester when he put on a movie. If you want students to engage with the class, it would be nice if the professor was at least awake. When he woke up, he proceeded to make passive aggressive comments about students in the class not paying attention. He was particularly passive aggressive to athletes in the class and he seemed to have a clear bias against student athletes. This is especially true for the basketball players whom he constantly belittled. Each class felt like a game Russian Roulette, where the outcomes would either be Tyson falling asleep, bullying students, or making problematic comments. It is truly hard to put into words how truly awful this class is.

response_text:
1. A more structured course syllabus, class period, class discussion.
2. More open, constructive, and multi-perspective discussions in class.
3. More support and adaptability from the faculty.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The lectures consist primarily of Professor Tyson or Professor Williams, sharing their personal experiences and anecdotes related to the topics covered in the readings. While these lived experiences are valuable, the lectures do not delve deeper into the subject matter or provide additional information to enhance understanding. Instead, the professors tend to repeat the same stories and narratives, which does not facilitate further learning or comprehension of the material. The note cards allow students to formulate their own thoughts and make connections to the readings, but during class, the discussions are heavily focused on the professors' perspectives, leaving little room for students to share their insights or explore their connections to the topics.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do not take this class. There is absolutely nothing that you can gain from taking this course. I learned more about Southern race relations in my high school than I did in this course. If you are uncomfortable with anti semitism and would like to learn, this class is not for you.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The syllabus underwent changes once the class began, which is generally not permitted. Initially, a take-home midterm was listed in the syllabus, but about a week before the midterm, it was abruptly changed to an in-class midterm without proper notice or consent from the students. By the time grades were returned for that midterm, the deadline to take the class on a satisfactory/unsatisfactory basis or withdraw had already passed. Additional assignments were introduced after this deadline, and the final exam was no longer the sole examination, contrary to what was stated in the syllabus. The grading is stringent, with all assessments being written responses, and any deviation from the professor's expected answers can result in low or even zero scores, immediately impacting overall grades. Throughout the course, students do not have access to a visible grade book or platform like Canvas, making it challenging to track their progress as the syllabus and assignments continue to change unexpectedly. To perform well, memorizing terms from the assigned readings is essential, as outside information is often dismissed, and only definitions from the specified texts are accepted for full credit.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my understanding of archives and the different mediums in which they can exist. I learned about important Black authors, photographers, and musicians that have shaped black consciousness through their work both in the United States and across Africa.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I believe this course was huge in developing my ways of engaging with archival theory. I've learned about Black art and the archive, Black aquatic archive theory, and I learned a generous amount from my classmates through the seminar format.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: While in this course, I learned to expand my perspective on the scope of archival materials. Because of the engagement with the readings, I now value the body as an archive. I also understand that archives possess the ability to dialogue. Most importantly, I gained a significant reading list and resources to support my arguments and theories that I would not have been aware of if it weren't for this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think about and narrate Black archival practice expansively (but also the importance of considering the consequences/perils of the impulse to recollect everything); How to think more critically about waterscapes as archives, and as liberatory spaces beyond how they've been narrated historically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Interpreting Archival Silence: This course deepened my understanding of how historical erasure operates and how silences in the archive are not accidental but structured. I learned to “read between the lines” and to think critically about whose stories are told—and whose are not.
Creative Engagement with Archival Material: Through our exposure to artists, writers, and scholars who use the archive as both material and metaphor, I developed new ways of thinking about memory, storytelling, and resistance. The course showed me how archives can be reimagined through poetry, performance, and visual art.
Diasporic and Transnational Thinking: I learned to think across geographies and histories—connecting the Black experience in the U.S., South Africa, and other parts of the diaspora. The course challenged me to think about the global entanglements of anti-Blackness and creative survival.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As someone who doesn't work a ton with theoretical frameworks and someone new to archiving, this was a great way for me to expand my own ideas of what an archive is and what the archive has the potential to be. Specifically in terms of the Black archive, I  have the following takeaways from the course1) Theoretical frameworks for archiving: In this course I  learned about the theoretical frameworks about the different forms of archiving. With each of the readings, I was introduced to a new idea or theory about the Black archive.2) redefining my ideas of the Black archive: this course really expanded my thinking about what an archive could be. I  enjoyed how we looked at different forms of archiving such as film, photography, and even forms of non-materiality like the ocean.3) interdisciplinary archival methods: I  really enjoyed this interdisciplinary class. We had people from various disciplines that added to the strength of the discussion.This allowed me to think through other ways that people think about emobidment and archiving outside of the traditional literary forms that I  am used to observing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot more about African countries and traditions, alternative ways of thinking about the archive, and how to write critically in response to archival theory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The archival visits to the Schomburg and Rubenstein which were framed by the theoretical texts we read throughout the course was enlightening and helped me to perceive the immensity of what it was to imagine the black body through these analytical tools. This coupled with the alternative forms of archival memory (photography, play writing, filmmaking, etc.) will definitely be useful in my disseration writing. 
Second, the guest speakers we periodically had in class helped to engage the class with the texts beyond surface-level analysis. We were able to tailor our questions or responses to the creator of said texts, rather than spending time on speculating possibilities of textual analysis. I found this interview style of class to be highly beneficial to my appreciation of what we were learning, and it further birthed analytical queries as to what the text entailed. 
Finally, hearing the responses from my classmates as to their analysis of what had been covered that week was beneficial to my understanding of the text, and helped me to think through the class in a fulfilling manner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First of all, this course introduced me to archival work in the practical, applied definition of the term. I was essentially going in blind although with the understanding that the archival process was (and is) front and center in my research and scholarly aspirations more generally. Our trip to the Schomburg Center,  as well as to the Rubenstein on a couple of occasions, really cultivated the feeling and process of archival practice from its most rudimentary to much more complex forms. In other words, the practical skills and methods referring to everything form applying for research profiles at the Schomburg to using finding aids to search for materials and beyond were all nurtured  by and through this course. But things do not just stop there. The theoretical knowledge gained in this course has been so vast that it would be nearly impossible to isolate one or two specific insights. I would say that this course cultivated a specific reading practice in me, which I intend to retain as I progress through my studies. Thinking archivally, and, specifically, thinking about the use of archival materials as forms of evidence, their placement in the texts we studied, the rhetorics built around them, and so forth, made me consistently consider the ethics of using the archives – especially those which such traumatic, heavy, or otherwise violence-laden sources. Although I certainly have room to improve, I feel like this course really required me to read closer than ever; to probe not only the arguments being presented, but also to scrutinize the archival sources being cited – often even trying to locate primary sources in order to compare and contextualize how certain citation were being implemented. Sometimes my discoveries were shocking with regard to certain decontextualized or otherwise heavily manipulated usages of primary material. In any case, I consider this a skill or even a reading method that I hope to transfer into my scholarship hence forth. Lastly, I have to mention the community of research fostered by this course. Through this course I have established working, collaborative friendships which I hope will persist. In my field, the caricature of the private, hermetic scholar still remains the more or less hegemonic image of what scholarship is or ought to be. This course absolutely challenged this image, and did so furthermore without resorting to the sorts of romanticized communities you often hear about in higher education. In a very material, working, and concrete sense, this class produced and actualized a real research community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Methods to engage and understand archival material. An expansion of what I conceive of as "the archive".  The importance of historiography and the difficulties Black people have faced in preserving their past experiences.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the seminar aspect of the course. Discussing the material with my peers was very helpful and allowed me to gain from their perspectives. I also enjoyed the guest speakers and learning about their work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was mainly seminar/discussion based after a week of reading and a reflection. I don't always enjoy when classes use repetitive methods of entering into the material, however, I believe that Khwezi and Chris are great facilitators and interject/guide the conversation so that the class time is fruitful for the participants.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would keep the guest visits a part of the course. Speaking with scholars exploring these topics and uncovering archives in such a powerful way has helped me form my methodologies and thesis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes! I definitely appreciate the option to do a creative project with accompanying writing and I think future students would also find this useful. I also liked how we focused on different categories of archives over the course of the semester (periodicals and print media, photographs, waterscapes, etc)—this gave breadth to an understanding of what an archive is and how they can function.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The balance between theory and creative expression made the course incredibly rich. The readings, while challenging at times, were thoughtfully curated and gave us a solid foundation for discussion. The Schomburg trip was an unforgettable experience—it grounded the theoretical in the tangible and emotional. I would definitely keep that as part of the course in future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors facilitated our learning through the formats of readings, written reflections, and trips to various archives. I  found each of these to be formative to my own personal experience in the course. With the reflections, I was able to express my own thoughts about the reading and generate ideas about the Black archive in formative ways. The trips to the archives allowed me to gain experience with handling written materials. Personally, I  enjoyed each of these components and found them to be useful for my own research and personal understandings of the archive.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class is discussion-based and relies heavily on the readings to facilitate these discussions. Additionally, the professors brought in some guest lecturers for some classes, and we were able to take a trip to the Schomburg library in New York City. I really enjoyed all the parts of the class! I liked how the readings included both classics in Black archival thought and some emerging research and artworks. These ideas were all new to me, even though I had taken classes about archives before. I suppose those focused more on literature by white people. However, these readings were all engaging and expanded my worldview a lot. The guest lecturers were all super nice in answering all of our questions and giving overviews of their work, which helped a lot in imagining how archival research can manifest in different genres of art. The trip to the Schomburg was also incredibly special. I had never been to Harlem before, and it was wonderful to see how Black thought and art could have really grown in times like the Harlem Renaissance. The Schomburg as a library was also really unique, and I felt lucky to have experienced it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The integration of guest speakers, physical place analysis, as well as archival research was important to my overall learning experience and enhanced my overall academic insight. In the future as an instructor, emphasis on embodied learning will definitely be crucial to my pedagogy.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The basic format of the course (weekly reading with discussion) was enhanced with frequent guest speakers and trips to the Rubenstein, and, of course, our Schomburg excursion. I'll keep it simply by saying that all of the above should be kept in forthcoming iterations of the course. The addition of public lectures and events was also very successful, as it not only augmented the learning environment and our grasp of course material, but it also allowed us to interact on a quite intimate level with invited scholars and other experts. This as well is, I think, worth retaining. I also always appreciated and found extremely useful Chris and Khwezi's insights and (let's call them, casual or impromptu) lectures. They clearly wanted to cultivate a discussion based classroom, and thus their input was not lecture heavy. Instead, their insights were laced and interwoven into the overall class discussion, which was to the benefit of the learning environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the course's co-taught nature. Both professors' styles complemented one another, and their strengths lent themselves to different areas of discussion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The professors were so knowledgeble about the course material and asked very insightful questions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The theory we read was incredibly stimulating. Even the text that didn't have to do with my field was generative in the way I approached my work.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course was very stimulating. We could have spent more at the Rubenstein Library.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The guest speakers (especially Nadia Davids and Brenda Sisane) enhanced the course, as did our trip to the Schomburg Center, and getting to explore not just the materials housed there but also getting to experience the physical space of the institution having read about it from Laura Helton's work earlier in the semester.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Many factors made this class stimulating, the course constantly pushed me to reframe how I think about history, evidence, and narrative. The readings were thought-provoking, and the guest lectures and class discussions challenged me to consider new frameworks and creative approaches.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Having the different perspectives from other students along with the speakers made this an intellectually stimulating environment. One way to add to this could be thinking about ways to increase our time in the archives that we have accessible to us via the Rubenstein, Wilson Library, etc. Being able to interact with the materials, I think would be able to help us put alot of these theories in praxis.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I had never taken an AAAS class at Duke before, so this was a real challenge for me to talk about a culture that wasn't my own or that I had little experience studying at a college level. It was also my first graduate class at Duke, so I was scared for sure! I felt super lucky to have had classmates and professors who were super smart and kind to me as I learned and who listened to my ideas. It was a positive learning environment centered on intellectual growth and radical thought, which felt unique to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Kwezi and Chris are phenomenal thinkers, and our discussions obviously reflected that. I feel that I would have benefitted from a more structured question format, instead of the open-ended discussion possibilities.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Lively discussion; engaging, provocative scholarship; frequent visitors and trips. All very stimulating. Wouldn't change much on this front.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I believe this course is incredibly stimulating and thoughtfully led. The student will thoroughly enjoy the course and its facilitators, Professor Khwezi and Professor Chris.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! This is not just a class—it’s a journey through memory, loss, and imagination. You’ll leave with a more expansive understanding of what archives are and what they can be. Come prepared to read deeply, think critically, and feel a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I  would tell future students to have an open mind about the course. I think when you hear about archives, it can be easy to have preconceived notions about what the archives are and how we are supposed to interact with the archives. Having an open mind when coming into the course can allow students to really benefit from the course and the ways in which this course challenges you to think about the Black archive in new ways.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take it, even if it feels outside of your scope! I definitely feel like a better person (hopefully) coming out of this course in that I can be more sensitive with the archives that I work with and that I can work towards more decolonization advocacy in that regard. The class can also easily be tailored to your own research and backgrounds, so there's a space for everyone in the class to bring what they know into the discussions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take advantage of the range of resources that this course will offer you. The hands-on experiences with archives as well as the interviews from guest speakers is crucial in developing your research expertise.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you get the reflections in on time, otherwise the group discussions may suffer a bit.

response_text: First of all, this course introduced me to archival work in the practical, applied definition of the term. I was essentially going in blind although with the understanding that the archival process was (and is) front and center in my research and scholarly aspirations more generally. Our trip to the Schomburg Center,  as well as to the Rubenstein on a couple of occasions, really cultivated the feeling and process of archival practice from its most rudimentary to much more complex forms. In other words, the practical skills and methods referring to everything form applying for research profiles at the Schomburg to using finding aids to search for materials and beyond were all nurtured  by and through this course. But things do not just stop there. The theoretical knowledge gained in this course has been so vast that it would be nearly impossible to isolate one or two specific insights. I would say that this course cultivated a specific reading practice in me, which I intend to retain as I progress through my studies. Thinking archivally, and, specifically, thinking about the use of archival materials as forms of evidence, their placement in the texts we studied, the rhetorics built around them, and so forth, made me consistently consider the ethics of using the archives – especially those which such traumatic, heavy, or otherwise violence-laden sources. Although I certainly have room to improve, I feel like this course really required me to read closer than ever; to probe not only the arguments being presented, but also to scrutinize the archival sources being cited – often even trying to locate primary sources in order to compare and contextualize how certain citation were being implemented. Sometimes my discoveries were shocking with regard to certain decontextualized or otherwise heavily manipulated usages of primary material. In any case, I consider this a skill or even a reading method that I hope to transfer into my scholarship hence forth. Lastly, I have to mention the community of research fostered by this course. Through this course I have established working, collaborative friendships which I hope will persist. In my field, the caricature of the private, hermetic scholar still remains the more or less hegemonic image of what scholarship is or ought to be. This course absolutely challenged this image, and did so furthermore without resorting to the sorts of romanticized communities you often hear about in higher education. In a very material, working, and concrete sense, this class produced and actualized a real research community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Methods to engage and understand archival material. An expansion of what I conceive of as "the archive".  The importance of historiography and the difficulties Black people have faced in preserving their past experiences.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the seminar aspect of the course. Discussing the material with my peers was very helpful and allowed me to gain from their perspectives. I also enjoyed the guest speakers and learning about their work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was mainly seminar/discussion based after a week of reading and a reflection. I don't always enjoy when classes use repetitive methods of entering into the material, however, I believe that Khwezi and Chris are great facilitators and interject/guide the conversation so that the class time is fruitful for the participants.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would keep the guest visits a part of the course. Speaking with scholars exploring these topics and uncovering archives in such a powerful way has helped me form my methodologies and thesis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes! I definitely appreciate the option to do a creative project with accompanying writing and I think future students would also find this useful. I also liked how we focused on different categories of archives over the course of the semester (periodicals and print media, photographs, waterscapes, etc)—this gave breadth to an understanding of what an archive is and how they can function.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The balance between theory and creative expression made the course incredibly rich. The readings, while challenging at times, were thoughtfully curated and gave us a solid foundation for discussion. The Schomburg trip was an unforgettable experience—it grounded the theoretical in the tangible and emotional. I would definitely keep that as part of the course in future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors facilitated our learning through the formats of readings, written reflections, and trips to various archives. I  found each of these to be formative to my own personal experience in the course. With the reflections, I was able to express my own thoughts about the reading and generate ideas about the Black archive in formative ways. The trips to the archives allowed me to gain experience with handling written materials. Personally, I  enjoyed each of these components and found them to be useful for my own research and personal understandings of the archive.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class is discussion-based and relies heavily on the readings to facilitate these discussions. Additionally, the professors brought in some guest lecturers for some classes, and we were able to take a trip to the Schomburg library in New York City. I really enjoyed all the parts of the class! I liked how the readings included both classics in Black archival thought and some emerging research and artworks. These ideas were all new to me, even though I had taken classes about archives before. I suppose those focused more on literature by white people. However, these readings were all engaging and expanded my worldview a lot. The guest lecturers were all super nice in answering all of our questions and giving overviews of their work, which helped a lot in imagining how archival research can manifest in different genres of art. The trip to the Schomburg was also incredibly special. I had never been to Harlem before, and it was wonderful to see how Black thought and art could have really grown in times like the Harlem Renaissance. The Schomburg as a library was also really unique, and I felt lucky to have experienced it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The integration of guest speakers, physical place analysis, as well as archival research was important to my overall learning experience and enhanced my overall academic insight. In the future as an instructor, emphasis on embodied learning will definitely be crucial to my pedagogy.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The basic format of the course (weekly reading with discussion) was enhanced with frequent guest speakers and trips to the Rubenstein, and, of course, our Schomburg excursion. I'll keep it simply by saying that all of the above should be kept in forthcoming iterations of the course. The addition of public lectures and events was also very successful, as it not only augmented the learning environment and our grasp of course material, but it also allowed us to interact on a quite intimate level with invited scholars and other experts. This as well is, I think, worth retaining. I also always appreciated and found extremely useful Chris and Khwezi's insights and (let's call them, casual or impromptu) lectures. They clearly wanted to cultivate a discussion based classroom, and thus their input was not lecture heavy. Instead, their insights were laced and interwoven into the overall class discussion, which was to the benefit of the learning environment.

I felt super lucky to have had classmates and professors who were super smart and kind to me as I learned and who listened to my ideas. response_text: Definitely take it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! This is not just a class—it’s a journey through memory, loss, and imagination. You’ll leave with a more expansive understanding of what archives are and what they can be. Come prepared to read deeply, think critically, and feel a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I  would tell future students to have an open mind about the course. I think when you hear about archives, it can be easy to have preconceived notions about what the archives are and how we are supposed to interact with the archives. Having an open mind when coming into the course can allow students to really benefit from the course and the ways in which this course challenges you to think about the Black archive in new ways.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take it, even if it feels outside of your scope! The class can also easily be tailored to your own research and backgrounds, so there's a space for everyone in the class to bring what they know into the discussions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to cross analyze different types of media when it came to southern African American literature, write blog posts weekly to express our thoughts about this, and discuss how they may connect to larger themes in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to use intertextuality to talk about contemporary southern literature and how it relates to many themes in race, identity and socio-economic issues still present today. I learned about unique African-American experiences  and the concept of the "Dirty South" as it relates to OutKast.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct critical analyses of contemporary literature, understanding the nuanced conversations about race and socioeconomic class in grappling with oppression and unjust systems. I also learned how to facilitate and engage in discussions with peers to analyze difficult passages and collectively understand its deeper meaning. I also learned how to discuss contemporary media like Beyoncé's visual album and Outkast's music in an academic setting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The first method I developed and strengthened in the course was the ability to think critically and to revise, the second was asking important questions about the text, and the third was engaging in a group discussion for long periods of time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was one of the most unique courses I have taken so far at Duke. The largest skill I've learned throughout this course is to deeply engage with literary works. This course teaches you how to critically analyze themes and meanings that may not be obvious on the surface. This course has taught me how to question literature and how to interpret what the author is trying to express.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I came into the class as someone who did not enjoy thinking about things on a deeper level, especially when it concerned issues I felt I did not have a control over. In this class we talked about issues in the Southern African American society, ranging from culture, slavery, to hip hop. This class taught me how to have academic discussions on issues and learn how to analyze content more critically and effectively. I have found myself not only a better speaker, but more able to form critical arguments and discussion points on the spot.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I absolutely loved this course and the opportunity to engage with contemporary literature and media to further my ability to analyze and reason about systemic racism and collective healing. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor McInnis is one of the most passionate professors or teachers I have ever had. I've never met someone as enthusiastic to teach their content to a group of students. Professor McInnis truly cares about what is taught in class and the deep topics that we are analyzing. What made this course so amazing and fascinating was Professor McInnis. Each day, he would show up to class with enthusiasm to go over class readings. Professor McInnis was so knowledgeable about his field that I would often stay after class to ask him about specific passages or unique real world applications of what we go over in class, and he would always take the time to answer my questions thoroughly.Lastly, Professor McInnis would always make sure to find time to meet with me for office hours outside of class if I needed it. There are very few professors who would meet at 6:00 PM on a Friday to answer a students questions. It truly shows how much Professor McInnis cares about his students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was a very respectful and welcoming environment. Everyone participated and all of were engaged in the conversations. Something I liked about Professor McInnis was how he facilitated discussions. There would be times where no one would know what to say and he would be able to ask questions or direct us towards a better discussion. For example, when we were supposed to be discussing an experimental text by Randall Kenan, no one said anything because we were all confused by the structure of the reading. He was able to give us a good explanation and change the format of his questions to help us have a good discussion.

This class changes the way that you think about the world around you. It allows you to see aspects of society that you would never notice on the surface.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Professor McInnis loves when students have a unique perspective on a reading.Lastly, and maybe most importantly, get to know Professor McInnis. Grading is also a bit tough!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learning critique and analyze pieces of art was insightful. I also learned about the medical gaze and glance which I never even knew existed. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the waves of feminism, about the intersection of the medical gaze and the male gaze, and about the ways that gender, class, race, sexuality and more interact to shape women’s experiences with breast cancer and its associated treatment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about breast cancer and how it is represented in various forms of art, such as paintings, photographs, journals, essays, poems, and other forms of writing. Beyond the topic, I was able to work on my writing skills, as we had multiple informal writings and formal writings throughout the semester, with ample feedback from Professor Lamm, so I could work on every piece of writing for the next one. I also improved my reading skills, pulling out the important parts of a piece and pulling out evidence to support it, and also my speaking skills as we did a lot of discussions in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) how to better analyze pieces of literature and artwork surrounding various themes of breast cancer, feminism, and intersectionality
2) the importance of representation and the various ways in which people's identities have historically been ignored, mocked, or silenced
3) a better understanding of the ways in which art and storytelling intersect and the way artists can infuse their works with important messages.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Lamm was great about facilitating learning through discussion groups as well as class brainstorming. I also really enjoyed the informal writing assignments for class, as they were a low pressure way to try your hand at writing about different aspects of the works that we have read and the artwork we have viewed. Finally, I really liked the the formal assignments built on the informal assignments, as your growth as a writer was structured into the class assignments.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our class discussions were very well-run and I appreciated the open space in which to develop thoughts. I also especially liked our group work and it would be nice to have a bit more of this earlier in the semester to get to know my classmates.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved how Professor Lamm would make it a very relaxing, open, and welcoming environment where I learned a lot from listening to others. I never felt bad for not talking as much as others, but also was not scared to share my own thoughts with a class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that the professor would send emails the day before each class reminding us of what we woudl be looking at the next day in class. This made it easy to figure out what readings/videos needed to be done before the class started the next year. I also liked the flipped classroom, as many thoughtful discussions and insights came from the professor allowing us to talk about the subject matter in class. I also loved the trip to the Nasher as it was another way to explore the themes and goals of the course reflected by an everyday example. I also liked that the papers were open-ended and allowed for the writer to reflect on their own experiences and pick the works we examined in class that most resonated with them. I would keep all of these elements for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: I would definitely recommend this course! question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are 3 "formal" writings which are only 3-4 full pages and 3-4 "informal writings" which are 2-3 paragraphs each (and a final reflection paper). You are allowed to "re-use" content from your informal writings to help guide your formal writings, in fact they are set up to prepare you for the formal writing. So really not too bad at all in terms of workload. Readings, on average, take no more than 3 hours per week.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As previously mentioned, this class did not ask students to deeply reflect on the texts we read. Additionally, the professor's lectures tended to go onto tangents about completely unrelated topics and overgeneralized the Black experience. I remember the professor once asking the class, "Who runs the Black household?" Ignoring the fact that the class was majority non-Black, the professor assumed everyone would emphatically answer "women," but that assumes so much. What if your students don't have mothers? What if your students are from a multiracial household? There were so many moments when the professor made gendered generalizations of the Black experience, which always seemed to just be grounded in his own experience. These generalizations of women were often meant to be positive, but the professor's support of women almost always felt patronizing. And, when given the opportunity to really interrogate the gender parity and its psychosocial impact on Black women, there was nothing to be said.

1. I learned how to analyze sources whilst deeply factoring in the author's background in order to truly understand their perspective on the matter.
2. I learned that capitalism is NOT inherent, but rather involved a lot of exploitation and integration within other systems that permitted its existence and flourishing.
3. I learned about the history of feudalism within Europe that preceded capitalism, and why this progression occurred in the first place.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed ways of connecting knowledge between the past and the present and attempted to apply complex economic and ethical theories to modern-day life. I also learned about the history of Capitalism, which has informed the way that I view the modern economic system, especially in the US. Finally, I learned about Marxism and Karl Marx's life which also provided me enough historical background to get a better understanding of capitalism as a system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My major is not related to history at all so there was a lot that I learned in this course that I was not introduced to before. The main thing that helped me was that we discussed our readings in class, and although some of the readings were “dense” or hard to understand, Dr. Shareef was sure to explain what the readings meant and to go over anything that we didn’t understand. After these discussions, I was able to get a clearer picture of the origins of capitalism and how our readings were tied together.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the skill of engaging with texts deeper through asking questions, taking in depth annotations, and making connections with other texts. This class has caused me to ask more questions when reading texts because of the historical claims the authors make pertaining to capitalism and labor. It is important to ask questions in order to increase understanding of the text. Additionally, I learned to take more in-depth annotations because of the semester project that requires students to analyze a text and explain its context, its value, and its views on labor and its laws. Additionally, there are certain terms in the class that are discussed in several texts, this has encouraged me to make comparisons among various texts in order to increase complex understanding.

response_text: I would like to say that if you are a good writer and you are interested in history then this will definitely be an easy A for you. If you keep up with the course readings and you like to engage in a lot of group discussions, then I do believe that this course could be intellectually stimulating for you, however once you get behind, it is difficult to catch up. There are really only two assignments of the midterm and the final project. However be careful which project you pick because one definitely requires more personal investment than the other. Professor Shaharazard is a wonderful person and definitely brings some enthusiasm to class as she is very passionate about the topics in this course. However, the way she leads class can be all over the place, so if you are someone that appreciates a lot of structure in the classroom, attending this class can often feel like a waste of time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, writing critical reviews, taking on different perspectives

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about three revolutions in far more depth, the French, Haitian, and Latin American Revolutions. I also became able to identify some specific themes that are prevalent in connecting these historic events, but also in the practice of history, more generally.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Role of Haitian revolution in the Americas.
Perspective of bottom up historical analysis as opposed to top down.
Latin American history

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze the interconnectedness of history. This course starting with the American, then French, then Haitian, and lastly Latin American Revolutions offered a unique way to analyze history. As most courses tend to focus on one region, this course clearly displayed how ideas and movements travel across nations and waters. History always appeared segmented, but this history class displayed how universal forms of oppression and sentiments of freedom are. I additionally learned the power of history from below. Analyzing the writings and stories of often overlooked figures, it made it clear how distorted history really is as the predominant narrative encompassing history surrounds powerful white men. Reading about the impact of mostly unknown figures it displayed the overwhelming role of grassroots movements in inciting revolution.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course deepened my understanding of the Age of Revolutions as a global phenomenon, not just a series of isolated national events. I learned to connect political upheaval in France and Haiti with broader patterns of colonial resistance and empire. I developed a strong grasp of comparative historical analysis—especially in evaluating how race, class, and ideology shaped different revolutionary movements.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learnt how to develop my analytical skills, especially regarding primary sources.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the factors that caused the revolutions studied, how the average person in those locations contributed to them, and how they were all connected.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing I learned is that revolutions are never just about one moment, they build up over time and come from deeper tensions. I also got better at reading primary sources and thinking about what people were really trying to say or do. And I started seeing how different revolutions connect across the world, like how the Haitian and French ones influenced each other.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Knowledge: the causes and effects of the American, French, Haitian, and Latin American revolutions. More specifically, I learned details about them that many prior courses have failed to teach. I learned how they are interconnected. I learned how minority groups including women played a role in these revolutions. I learned a lot!
Methods: I learned to identify bias from an author based on their socio-economic-racial group. 
Ways of thinking: I learned that the answers to things are more complex than they seem. For example, it is not just enlightenment thought and bad monarchs that caused these revolutions (what is taught in most courses). there are so many more reasons and complexities which we covered in this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analyzing different perspectives, and critiquing authors/writers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about studying history with a bottom-up approach rather than a top-down approach. I learned about substantial overlap between Latin American revolutions and the American and French revolutions. I learned how to efficiently read and analyze scholarly sources.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about many figures involved in the age of revolutions. Before this class I didn't have much of an understanding of the history from below approach in these revolutions. I enjoyed learning about Toussaint Louverture and the Haitian revolution.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to examine history from the bottom, more effectively critically review primary and secondary sources, and became more skilled at presenting historical research findings in a cohesive and meaningful presentation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about different historiographical approaches to looking at this era of history ("history from above" and "history from below") and the merits and drawbacks of each. I also learned about historical events such as the Haitian Revolution and the Latin American wars of independence which I had limited knowledge about beforehand. Finally, I learned more about under-taught figures in American/French revolutionary history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Historical analysis

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In the course, I developed critical thinking skills when examining labels and concepts like Latino and Latinidad. I learned about the history of the Latinx community in the United States and gained insight into issues like discrimination and assimilation that followed mass migration. I learned about the relevance of music in Latinx culture and thought about the many ways it can be used to express and explore culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Coming into the class, I had some pretty big assumptions about the general content of the class. At first, I didn't think the course was going to center on US Latinx studies; I thought it was
going to focus on the history of Latin American countries and how those become affected by US intervention. Personally, I truly enjoy the direction the course is going. Learning about the history
of Latinos in the US, their struggles, their legacy, is a rich topic that I had previously not had the resources to understand. I've always wanted to learn more about this but I've never really had
the impetus to do so. I think it is so interesting to talk about these historical events, like the Chicano movement or the labor strikes, and tell my friends about them. It's a part of history that
goes unnoticed and it's worthy of bringing up everyone once in a while during a conversation. Outside of that, I feel like this class has made me more conscious of the continual Latino
presence in the US and what people are doing to combat injustice. I've done research and learned about powerful organizations, both in North Carolina and my hometown of Miami. It's
amazing seeing that everywhere there are communities like these all fighting for visibility and justice. I gain a lot from the music component of the course, and connect it to other music classes I've
taken at Duke. It's interesting seeing the connection between how the music we study is composed and what the music is representing. Understanding the Chicano movement through
song is a beautiful way to look at history. A song I particularly found touching was "Urbano's song". It was by far one of the saddest songs I've heard this year, and I still listen to it in my
 spare time.More concisely I learned:
- How to analyze Latino history and research topics in Latino studies.
- How to make a community facing project 
- How service learning can be used to supplement a class as well as engage with the surrounding community.

He also made clear the differences between different types of soul and made it clear to us what we would be quizzed on and how.

response_text: I loved having two professors for this course. Professor Neal brought expertise on black music and black pop culture. Together, they were a great team of teachers who introduced us to so much music and used this music and creative assignments (performances, improv assignments, readings) to keep us engaged and learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In the Jazz Music Seminar: Giants of Jazz class, I developed a deeper appreciation for the history and evolution of jazz. I learned how key figures in jazz shaped the genre and influenced its growth over time. The class also enhanced my understanding of jazz improvisation, especially how musicians use scales, chord progressions, and rhythm to create spontaneous solos. Additionally, I explored the different styles of jazz, from early forms to more modern developments, and how cultural changes impacted the music, allowing me to see jazz as a dynamic and evolving art form.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment in this class was highly engaging, with the instructor fostering a welcoming and interactive atmosphere. I particularly appreciated the open discussions, which encouraged critical thinking and allowed us to dive deeper into the music and its cultural context. For future years, I would definitely recommend keeping the use of real musical examples and class discussions, as they were key to understanding the material in a more immersive and meaningful way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because it combined rich historical context with a deep dive into the music itself, allowing us to appreciate not only the sound but also the cultural and social influences behind jazz. The way the course connected different jazz styles across eras and explored the innovations of musicians made me think critically about the genre’s evolution. The listening sessions and discussions encouraged active engagement, challenging me to listen more attentively and analyze the music on a deeper level. To make it even more intellectually stimulating, incorporating guest lectures or workshops with musicians could provide additional perspectives and first-hand insights into the music-making process. Overall, the class did an excellent job of fostering curiosity and expanding my understanding of jazz.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was very intellectually stimulating. There's still so much more to explore in jazz, but it's great to have a foundational understanding of the history and cultural context behind the music, which really sets the stage for our appreciation of the genre. Whereas before I started this course, I didn't know the differences between any types of jazz subgenres or artists. We've come a long way and I'm tremendously grateful of that

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're considering taking this course, I highly recommend it! It's an engaging and insightful exploration of jazz, offering both historical context and an in-depth look at the music itself. The course structure, which blends lectures, listening sessions, and discussions, really helps deepen your understanding of the genre and its evolution. Even if you don't have a background in music, you'll walk away with a greater appreciation for jazz and its cultural significance. Overall, it’s a great course for anyone interested in music, history, or cultural studies.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is lecture-heavy, but Prof. Waggoner is an amazing lecturer—he has his way with words, he's very articulate, and can really delve deep into a topic to present it thoroughly. Lecture is very substantive—I'd encourage you to take some notes and definitely write down the names of songs and artists you find interesting. I've added a lot of these songs to my playlist recently, but I hope you take it however far you want to go. Finally, this class has truly changed my understanding of jazz, especially the more subtle interdisciplinary connections between subjects like musical expression, music theory, American history, and pop culture. Taking this course has given me a much better idea of what jazz is foremost, and has also allowed me the means to appreciate the cultural and historical factors that have inspired what it's become today.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Some skills and insights that I developed in this course include critical and analytical thinking, close readings of literature and film, and academic writing. 
1. In film, everything is intentional. While a major aspect of film is entertainment, films are attempt to "say" things. 
2. In order to get at what a film is trying to "say," pay attention to what's there (color, space, storytelling, dialogue, etc.) but, perhaps more importantly, note what is absent. 
3. Films converse between each other all the time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely suggest taking Race, Film, Religion. Even if this class isn't offered, definitely take a class with Dr. Winters before leaving Duke! Film watching for the class was fun, and class discussions further facilitated my understanding of film analysis (even for other classes I'm in).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I have never taken a class about film or religion before this and Professor Winters makes the content very accessible for everyone. I learned a lot about the history of black film and how to critically analyze film.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend this course! It is very intellectually stimulating and not much work. Dr. Winters is very knowledgeable and is an amazing professor!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come prepared to think about film in a different way. We often talk about "closely" reading a film that couldn't be more important for this course. May attention to everything (the camera, the lighting, the music, the dialogue, etc.) because everything is intentional and therefore significant.
