question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading foundational philosophical texts from the centers and margins really transform my mindset, helps me academically, and religious thoughts. The reading list is both wide in scope and generatively constructed. Ideas and resonance between old european canon and african american studies' texts are outstandingly good.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I read authors I had never read before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned more about existentialism and nihilism. Those were concepts I wasn't familiar with coming into the course. I appreciated the opportunity to challenge the traditional existentialist canon that centers white men. As a non-white student this was helpful in getting and keeping me engaged in the course. I really appreciated the was that Professor Winters paired traditional existential readings with those that engaged gender, race, and class in different ways. I was also encouraged to think about the ways other scholars engage with themes from existentialism.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Sitting in circle. Giving ample room for first impression of the texts. Introducing each text before the text is assigned (a week before) and when discussion about to start (on the week).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the wide variety of authors we read from a number of different disciplines that all wrote on existentialism. That, along with the variety of disciplines being studied in the class made the course very interesting and covered a wide breadth of material.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The syllabus was interesting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the class discussions. It was helpful to have Professor Winters provide context before allowing us to explore deeper the themes and concepts. I also really like the course progression/ structure of the course. I found the fiction texts helpful in further underlying what we discussed with other readings.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Please give room after discussion to share to us your thoughts in a more systematic form, also of other "respected" interpreters. These are extremely important

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were interesting, but the course was cross-listed in too many departments. There was no overall cohesiveness to the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings and the responses of my peers made the class stimulating. I was able to engage with readings at varying levels of accessibility. Some required more in-depth reading that challenged me to attempt to engage with texts that I found difficult to read and understand. I also found the probings of Professor Winter stimulating.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Just take it. Wont regret it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend Dr. Winters as a professor, but I would not recommend this course unless you are particularly interested in philosophy. The other ideas promised for this course were not present; I would not recommend this course for someone interested in Religion.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely recommend a class with Professor Winters. He integrates well Black Studies, religious studies, and philosophy. He brought a unique perspective to Religion, Existentialism, and Nihilism that helps to provide insight into how different philosophical beliefs can play out in the everyday as well as the ways that identity and context shape how we engage with certain themes and ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about race and its structural and material impact on today's society. I also learned how to synthesize papers and understand that different sources have different perspectives and it is important to look at them critically. I was able to present my knowledge of a topic in depth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how racism is everywhere, how it is structures, and the different stories of different races perceptions of racism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course encouraged me to view world issues from a new, different perspective and has inspired me to continue my education in the sociology field. Specifically, this class taught me that racism is essentially the root of all issues that occur in the world. In addition, this class allowed me to develop my collaboration skills, a valuable skill that has always been and will continue to be used in my academics and beyond.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of eye-opening insights in this class. For example, I gained a vast understanding of the systemic hardships and inequities that Asian Americans have had to face in American history that is simply not talked about in American history. It was also very nice to have certain aspects of my own Asian American experience articulated, validating my experiences of racism and insecurity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course served as an introduction into the social construction of race and how that's played an important role in defining the history of all ethnic groups in the United States. Throughout the semester, we learned about the different laws, social norms, and cultural movements that contributed to the development and continuation of racism. Most importantly, the class discussed the effects of said racism, and explored how they've continued to ensure white supremacy in modernity. Another important factor covered was the concept of color-blind racism, which fundamentally argues that today's racism is maintained through subtle means that appear to uphold equality.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor and the TA were great in keeping the class engaging. I learned a lot from the class and the lectures were fun.

I would keep the class discussion aspect of the class.

response_text: My overall advice is to at least skim the readings if you aren't able to do them all before class. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: An understanding of African American Independent Cinema- understanding its development in dialogue and opposition with mainstream cinema, understanding the 4 phases of it, and critically watching these films for their subliminal messages and subtext.
